answer: For Work Year 2023 (WY2023) onwardsAll Net Trade Income (NTI) declarations for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) can be made with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) by filing a tax return. There is no need to file separate declarations with CPF Board.If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) to IRAS viamyTax Portalwhich will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass.If you have declared your NTI with IRAS, you need not declare your income again to CPF Board.

question: How will I know when my digital notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons is ready for viewing?
answer: You will receive an email notification to view your digital notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons via the self-employment dashboard when it is ready. If you do not have a registered email with CPF Board, you will receive an SMS notification instead. If you do not have a registered email address or mobile number, your notice will be sent to you in hardcopy at your residential address.To ensure you receive prompt alerts when your notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons is ready, please update your contact details via theaccount services pageafter logging in with your Singpass.

question: When will CPF Board start issuing the notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons digitally?
answer: Since 1 November 2024, CPF Board has been issuing the notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons digitally.You will receive an email or SMS notification to view your digital notice via theself-employment dashboardwhen it is ready.If you wish to receive a hardcopy notice instead, please update your notification preference by completing thenotification preference form. Your updated notification preference will take effect for any subsequent notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons.

question: What should I do if I wish to receive the notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons in hardcopy?
answer: If you wish to receive your notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons via hardcopy instead, you may update your notification preference via thenotification preference formusing your Singpass. The hardcopy notice will be mailed to you at your residential address.Your updated notification preference will take effect for any subsequent notice of CPF contributions thereafter.

question: I have previously chosen to receive my notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons in hardcopy. Can I still change my preference?
answer: Yes. Regardless of your current preference, you can update your preference anytime by completing thenotification preference form.Your updated notification preference will take effect for any subsequent notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons thereafter.

question: I have updated my preference via the notification preference form. Does this preference apply to other notifications sent by CPF Board?
answer: The notification preference only applies to the notice of CPF contributions for self-employed persons. Your updated notification preference will take effect for any subsequent notice of CPF contributions thereafter.

question: What is the period for income declaration to IRAS?
answer: If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) to IRAS viamyTax Portalwhich will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass.

question: I used to declare my income to CPFB to determine my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)/excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions for the year. Why is CPFB no longer accepting income declarations?
answer: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has been appointed as the single collecting agency for all SEPs’ income information from Work Year 2023 (or Year of Assessment 2024). This means that all SEPs will now declare their net trade income (NTI), including all other sources of income derived from Work Year 2023, to IRAS. SEPs who receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS or meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), will need to complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.SEPs who do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax may declare their self-employed net trade income (NTI), including all other sources of income derived from Work Year 2023, to IRAS viamyTax Portalwhich will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.SEPs will receive a Notice of Computation (NOC) from IRAS if they are required to make MediSave contributions, after IRAS has issued a Notice of Assessment for the relevant Year of Assessment.

question: What if my net trade income for the year is zero or negative?
answer: If your net trade income (NTI) is zero or negative for the year, you do not need to make any MediSave contribution for the year.You will still be required to pay your outstanding MediSave payable for the years you were self-employed.

question: What is net trade income?
answer: Net trade income is your gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS).

question: I have more than one source of trade income. Do I have to contribute to MediSave for all of them?
answer: Your MediSave contributions are based on the annual net trade income (NTI) from all your trades. If you have a yearly NTI of more than $6,000 from all your trades, you’re required to make contributions to your MediSave Account.You can refer to thisexampleof how MediSave payable is computed on multiple sources of NTI.

question: How do I apply to adjust my CPF Contributions from the firm's account to a self-employed person's account?
answer: You may submit an online application viamy cpfdigital servicesusing Singpass to adjust your CPF Contributions from the firm’s account to your self-employed account.The adjustment request must be made within one year from the date of payment.

question: I am a self-employed person. Can I contribute to my MediSave together with my employees' CPF using the CPF Payment Form (CPF 91)?
answer: You’re required to make your MediSave payable separately from your employees' CPF. This is because payments made using the CPF Payment Form (CPF 91) will be credited as employer contributions and will not be recognized as self-employed payments.If you would like to make CPF contributions as a self-employed person, there arevarious waysto do so.

question: What are the benefits of contributing to MediSave by GIRO?
answer: GIRO allows you to contribute to your MediSave Account over a period of 12 monthly instalments. It is most convenient as the contributions are automatically deducted from your bank account and you can easily monitor them. Contributing to MediSave by GIRO also provides a hassle-free licence application and renewal process.You may apply to pay via GIRO online (list of participating banks) or by mail (for other banks).Payment modeDetailsGIROUsingmy cpfdigital services (list of participating banks)Log in with your Singpass.Submit theSet up GIRO for MediSave contributionsapplication.Check the status of your GIRO application via Activities.Mail (for other banks)Download and complete theApply for GIRO for MediSave Contributionsform (FORM SE GIRO (PDF, 0.2MB)).Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form.We will notify you of your GIRO application status once the bank has processed it.

question: How can I make my MediSave contributions?
answer: There are several ways you can contribute to your MediSave. The most convenient way is via GIRO, which allows automatic monthly deductions from your bank account.Payment modeDetailsGIROUsingmy cpfdigital services (list of participating banks)Log in with your Singpass.Submit theSet up GIRO for MediSave contributionsapplication.Check the status of your GIRO application via Activities.Mail (for other banks)Download and complete theApply for GIRO for MediSave Contributionsform (FORM SE GIRO (PDF, 0.2MB)).Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form.We will notify you of your GIRO application status once the bank has processed it.PayNow QRRequest an instalment plan or contribute to your MediSave payable in full via theManage your MediSave payableform.Cash/ NETS/ CashCardMake MediSave contributions (any amount) via cash, NETS or CashCard at any SingPost branch.You may view your MediSave contributions on the Self-employment dashboard. To accessmy cpfDigital Services – Self-employment dashboard, please log in to theCPF websiteusing your Singpass.

question: How can I check whether I have any MediSave payable as a self-employed person?
answer: You can check your MediSave payable by logging in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass.You can apply for yourSingpass onlineif you do not have one.

question: Can I apply for a licence/renew my licence if I have outstanding MediSave payable?
answer: Licensing authorities will only process your licence application/renewal if your MediSave payable is up-to-date, that is, you have either paid your MediSave in full or have an active GIRO arrangement with the Board to settle your MediSave payable via instalments.You can check your MediSave payable statement, pay your MediSave contributions in full or request for an instalment plan on theSelf-employment dashboard. To accessmy cpfDigital Services – Self-employment dashboard, please log in to theCPF websiteusing your Singpass.You can apply for yourSingpass onlineif you do not have one. You may wish to note that you will be cleared for licence application/renewal after making a full payment or upon your first successful GIRO deduction.Refer to thisguidefor step-by-step instructions on retrieving information on your eligibility for licence application/ renewal.

question: If I do not earn any net trade income for the year, can I renew my licence?
answer: You can renew your licence so long as there is no outstanding MediSave payable or you have signed up to pay your MediSave payable via monthly GIRO instalments.

question: If I do not intend to renew my licence, do I need to settle my outstanding MediSave payable?
answer: You’re required to pay your outstanding MediSave payable even if you do not intend to renew your licence.

question: Why is MediSave important for self-employed persons?
answer: MediSave can be used for healthcare needs, such as to pay for MediShield Life premiums or hospitalisation cost. It is therefore important that self-employed persons set aside a portion of their income to build up their MediSave savings, in anticipation of their future healthcare needs, especially during old age when they have stopped working.

question: What benefits do self-employed persons enjoy from making MediSave contributions?
answer: When you contribute to MediSave, you enjoy:Up to 6% interest1per annum on your MediSave savingsSavings in the MediSave Account earn 4% interest1per annum, and the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances earns an additional 1% interest per annum. Members aged 55 and above will also enjoy an additional 1% interest per annum on the first $30,000 of their combined CPF balance from 1 January 2016.Tax relief of up to 37% of your annual net trade income (NTI), the CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 or the actual amount contributed by you, whichever is lower. No tax relief is given if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.Use of MediSave savingsto pay for a variety of medical expensesHassle-free licence application and renewalYou may also be eligible forWorkfare Income Supplement (WIS)payouts of up to $2,800 annually.1Based on the current 4% interest rate floor for MediSave savings. Refer toCPF interest ratesfor the current rates.

question: Do I still have to contribute to my MediSave if I am both a self-employed person as well as an employee working in another company?
answer: If you earn an annualnet trade incomeof more than $6,000, you are required to contribute to your MediSave Account as a self-employed person (SEP).CPF contribution is based on your total income. Therefore, an SEP who is also an employee at the same time, is required to contribute to MediSave as an SEP. This is the same for employees who hold more than one job and are required to pay CPF contributions for all the wages they receive.However, you can apply to limit the MediSave payable on your self-employed income if your total employment income (excluding Additional Wages*) for the year exceeds the maximum total annual income. You may refer to thisFAQfor more information on the conditions for this application.*Additional Wages are wage supplements which are not granted wholly and exclusively for the month. Examples are the annual bonus, leave pay, incentive and other payments made at intervals of more than a month.To limit your MediSave contributions, you maywrite to us.

question: Do I still have to contribute to MediSave as a self-employed person even though my MediSave balance has reached the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS)?
answer: As a self-employed person (SEP), you are still required to make MediSave contributions even if you have met the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). This is the same for employees.The MediSave amount above the BHS will be transferred to your CPF Special Account (SA) or Retirement Account (RA), which have interest rates equal or higher than that of the MediSave Account. The BHS cap and overflow arrangement are intentionally planned to avoid over savings in MediSave and to supplement your retirement savings. These overflows which end up in your SA or RA can be withdrawn according to the withdrawal guidelines. For members who have met the Full Retirement Sum in their SA or RA, the savings in excess of the BHS will be transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA). Savings in the OA can be used for other purposes such as housing repayment.

question: Why do I still need to contribute to MediSave even though I already have enough savings for my healthcare needs?
answer: With rising healthcare costs, it is important to have enough savings for your healthcare needs. Contributing regularly to MediSave will help you build up your savings over your working life. These savings can help you meet your own as well as your loved ones’ hospitalisation expenses under unforeseen circumstances.

question: Why do I still need to contribute to MediSave as a self-employed person even though I have already bought insurance for myself?
answer: All working Singapore residents are required to contribute to their MediSave as a form of savings for their own and their loved ones’ healthcare needs.Many Singaporeans have bought private hospital insurance plans in the form of Integrated Shield Plans, or IPs. IPs comprise of two parts – MediShield Life (MSL) which is a universal basic health insurance plan, and additional private insurance coverage. MediSave can be used to pay the premiums for both MSL and private insurance, up to the current withdrawal limit.Hence, private medical insurance serves to complement rather than replace your MediSave savings.

question: I have substantial balances in my Ordinary and Special Accounts. Can I use the available funds to offset my MediSave payable?
answer: The three CPF accounts, Ordinary, Special and MediSave Accounts, serve different purposes. While Ordinary and Special Account savings are meant for retirement, your MediSave Account savings are for your healthcare needs. Thus, the balances in your Ordinary and Special accounts cannot be used to settle your MediSave payable.

question: What are the conditions for applying to limit my MediSave payable as a self-employed person?
answer: You can apply to limit your MediSave payable if your total employment income (excluding Additional Wages) for the year exceeds the maximum total annual income.Additional Wages are wage supplements which are not granted wholly and exclusively for the month. Examples are the annual bonus, leave pay, incentive and other payments made at intervals of more than a month.Please refer to the table below for the total employment income (excluding Additional Wages) that qualifies you to limit your MediSave contributions as a self-employed person.YearMaximum Total Annual Income(excluding Additional Wages)1993 - 2003$72,0002004$66,0002005$60,0002006 - 2010$54,0002011$56,0002012 - 2015$60,0002016 - 2022$72,0002023$73,2002024$81,6002025$88,8002026 onwards$96,000

question: I have a partnership firm. Do all partners need to make MediSave contributions before renewing the business licence?
answer: All partners (if they derive trade income) must fulfil their MediSave payable before the business licence can be renewed.

question: Do I have to pay my MediSave payable when I am no longer self-employed?
answer: You’re still required to settle any outstanding MediSave payable, as it is compulsory under the CPF Act to contribute to your MediSave Account for the years that you were self-employed.

question: I am holding two types of licences (e.g. LTA and ACRA). Do I have to contribute to MediSave for both licences?
answer: The MediSave payable is based on your annual net trade income (NTI) derived as a self-employed person and not the number of licences. If you have a total yearly NTI of more than $6,000 from your licence(s), you are required to make contributions to your MediSave Account.

question: How can I check if I am eligible for licence application or renewal?
answer: It depends on whether you are a self-employed person or a non-self-employed person.For self-employed personsYou can check if you are eligible for licence application or renewal by logging in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass. You can apply for yourSingpass onlineif you do not have one.Your licensing agency, real estate company or financial institution may request for a copy of your MediSave payable statement. To retrieve your MediSave payable statement, click the PDF function icon at the top right of the MediSave payable statement after logging into Singpass.Refer to thisguidefor step-by-step instructions on retrieving your MediSave payable statement.For non-self-employed personsYou can check if you are eligible for licence application by logging in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass through ‘Check your status’ under Hassle-Free licence application/ renewal. You can apply for yourSingpass onlineif you do not have one.You will be able to view a message indicating your licence application eligibility. Your licensing agency, real estate company or financial institution may request for a screenshot of the message to facilitate your application.Refer to thisguidefor step-by-step instructions on retrieving information on your eligibility for licence application.

question: I do not have outstanding MediSave payable as a self-employed person. Can I make MediSave contributions to offset my future payables?
answer: You may make MediSave contributions to offset your future payables, up to the prevailing CPF Annual Limit.The total CPF contributions (voluntary and mandatory CPF contributions) made for the calendar year should not exceed the prevailing CPF Annual Limit. Any contributions made in excess of the CPF Annual Limit will be refunded without interest.The Board must receive the MediSave contributions by the last working day of the year for them to be counted towards the year’s CPF Annual Limit. Backdating of MediSave contributions to previous years is not allowed.You can enjoytax reliefon your MediSave contributions, if eligible, based on your annual net trade income.

question: I have outstanding MediSave payable. Why am I not allowed to make partial payment to offset my MediSave payable under the Manage your MediSave Payable form (MMSP)?
answer: This is to encourage and make it easier for self-employed persons to be up-to-date with their MediSave payable. You can conveniently request instalment plan or make full payment for your MediSave payable viaManage your MediSave Payable(MMSP). This allows for hassle-free licence application/renewal while being up-to-date with your MediSave payable.

question: What are the MediSave contribution rates for self-employed persons (SEPs)?
answer: Your MediSave payable is based on your age and net trade income for the year. You can use theSelf-Employed MediSave Contribution Calculatorto calculate the amount of MediSave you need to contribute.View the MediSave rates applicable for2026(PDF, 75KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2025(PDF, 74KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2024(PDF, 74KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2023(PDF, 74KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for the years2016 to 2022(PDF, 0.2MB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2015(PDF, 23KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2014(PDF, 60KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2013(PDF, 54KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2012(PDF, 52KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2011(PDF, 28KB).View the MediSave rates applicable for2010(PDF, 28KB).View the MediSave rates applicable forthe years 2007 to 2009(PDF, 19KB).View the MediSave rates applicable forthe years 1992 to 2006(PDF, 19KB).

question: I have made a top-up to my CPF accounts, do I still have to make MediSave contributions to offset my MediSave payable?
answer: The contributions allocated to your MediSave Account via your top up to CPF accounts will not be used to offset your MediSave payable.If you want to make MediSave contributions to offset your outstanding (via instalment plan or full payment) or future MediSave payable, you may do so via theManage your MediSave Payableform.

question: I have outstanding MediSave payable. Why am I not able to make voluntary top-ups to my or my loved ones' CPF accounts?
answer: Self-employed persons making top ups to their MediSave accounts or on another person’s behalf are required to be up-to-date with their MediSave payable (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan).You can conveniently request instalment plan or make full payment for your MediSave payable via theManage your MediSave payable form. You will be able to make voluntary top-ups to your or your loved ones’ CPF Accounts when you are up-to-date with your MediSave payable.Conversely, you will be able to receive voluntary top-ups from your loved ones if they are up-to-date with their MediSave payable (if applicable).

question: What is the cut-off date for self-employed MediSave contributions to be eligible for tax relief?
answer: To be eligible for tax relief for the year, theMediSavecontributions made by self-employed persons must be credited to their CPF accounts by the last working day of the year.If you have madeMediSavecontributions during the year, the contribution amounts will be automatically transmitted to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for tax relief in the following year.There is no tax relief for yourMediSaveCPF contributions if your assessed net trade income for the year of assessmentis zero or negative.For more details on tax deductions, please visit theIRAS websiteor call the Individual Income Tax / Property Tax Helpline at 1800-356-8300.

question: I have made a voluntary top-up to my CPF accounts, why does the voluntary contribution allocated to my MediSave account not offset my MediSave payable?
answer: With effect from 29 May 2024, the member and self-employed person’s “Contribute to my three CPF accounts” forms have been combined and renamed as “Top up CPF accounts”. This is to simplify the process in making voluntary top-ups, regardless of whether you are earning income as a self-employed person. You will continue to enjoy self-employed tax relief on these voluntary top-ups if you meet theeligibility criteria.As these top-ups are voluntary in nature, the voluntary contribution allocated to your MediSave Account will not be used to offset your mandatory MediSave payable, and consequently will not meet the MediSave requirement for Workfare for self-employed persons. The intent is for self-employed persons to prioritise their mandatory MediSave contributions over voluntary contributions, and help self-employed persons to first set aside sufficient savings for their healthcare needs. Self-employed persons who wish to make mandatory contributions towards their MediSave payable, and to qualify for Workfare, should do so via theManage your MediSave payable, instead of making voluntary contributions.

question: Can I enjoy tax relief as a self-employed person when I contribute to my MediSave Account to offset my outstanding MediSave payable, pre-pay my future MediSave payable or make voluntary top-ups to my CPF accounts?
answer: Self-employed persons (SEPs) can enjoy tax relief on their MediSave or CPF contributions based on their annual net trade income (NTI). However, there is no tax relief for your MediSave or CPF contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.You can enjoy tax relief on your MediSave or CPF contributions based on whichever is lower:37% of assessable income; orCPF Annual Limit of $37,740; orActual amount contributed by youPlease note that there will be a personal income tax relief cap of $80,000 which will apply from Year of Assessment 2018. This cap applies to the total amount of all tax reliefs claimed, including any relief on voluntary contributions made on or after 1 January 2017.As accepted MediSave or CPF contributions cannot be refunded, you should evaluate whether you would benefit from tax relief on your voluntary CPF top-ups and make an informed decision. Please visit theInland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)website for more information.

question: How do I make payment for my MediSave payable?
answer: If you would like tomake payment for your MediSave payable, you may follow the steps below:Read and accept the Disclaimer, and click “Start”.Login with your Singpass.Select“Make full payment” to pay your outstanding MediSave payable in full; or“Request new instalment plan” if you wish to request an instalment plan for your outstanding MediSave payable.If you have selected “Make full payment”:Read and accept the “Terms and Conditions”, and click “Submit”.Make payment by scanning the PayNow QR with your PayNow participating bank’s app. Please note that the transaction amount is capped at your PayNow limit with your bank.Note: If you do not have outstanding MediSave payable and wish to pre-pay your future MediSave payable incurred as a self-employed person, you may do so by entering the amount you wish to contribute.  The amount that you can pre-pay is subject to the Annual Limit. This option will only be available if you are eligible to pre-pay your future MediSave payables.If you have selected “Request new instalment plan”:Key in your current monthly income,Select plan offered. You may be prompted to indicate your preferred monthly instalment amount and to upload supporting documents showing your income and expenses. When you are done, click “Next”.Read and accept the “Terms and Conditions” and click “Submit”.Note: If you are not on a GIRO arrangement for your MediSave payable, you will be required tosign up for GIROto pay the MediSave contributions via instalments. Your instalment plan will only take effect after we have processed your application, and your GIRO application has been approved by your bank.

question: When is the deadline to make my MediSave contributions?
answer: (a) For self-employed persons (SEPs) who were issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA)/ Non-tax advice by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS):Amount of ContributionsPayable ByComputed based on your age and Net Trade Income (NTI) assessed by IRAS. You will be issued with a “Notice of Computation (NOC) of CPF Contributions (MediSave)” from IRAS30 days from the date of issue of the NOC(b) For SEPs who were not issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA)/ Non-tax advice by IRAS:For Relevant Years 2020 onwardsAmount of ContributionsPayable ByComputed based on your age and declared NTI to CPF Board30 days from the date of issue of Notice of Contribution from CPF BoardFor Relevant Years 2019 and earlierAmount of ContributionsPayable ByComputed based on your age and declared NTI to CPF Board31 May of the following year

question: Why does CPF Board take self-employed persons to court for not contributing to their MediSave?
answer: Self-employed persons (SEPs) are required under the CPF Act to contribute to their MediSave. This ensures that SEPs have enough MediSave savings for their healthcare needs, especially during old age when they have stopped working. SEPs without enough MediSave savings and MediShield Life cover may need to tap on other sources of funds such as their family members’ MediSave savings should they be hospitalised.The CPF Board will continue to be flexible towards those with genuine financial difficulties. SEPs can requestinstalment plansto settle the outstanding amounts over a reasonable period. The CPF Board will only take recalcitrant defaulters to court as the last resort.

question: What is the approach taken by CPF Board in enforcing MediSave contributions from self-employed persons?
answer: Each year, self-employed persons (SEPs) are notified by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) via the Notice of Computation (NOC) to pay their MediSave payable in full or by monthly instalments through GIRO. The CPF Board may enforce payments from SEPs only if they have failed to make payments after repeated reminders.

question: What if self-employed persons do not respond to the Notice of Computation (NOC)?
answer: If self-employed persons (SEPs) do not respond to the NOC, the CPF Board may issue them a Letter of Demand and Offer which requires them to pay up their outstanding MediSave contributions, together with the payment of the composition amount offered. If there is still no payment, the Board may issue them a Notice to Attend Court (NTA). A sample is appended.NTA for offences before 31 Dec 2021 (PDF, 0.1MB)NTA for offences on or after 31 Dec 2021 (PDF, 0.1MB)SEPs who are brought to court may face a fine of up to $5,000 or imprisonment of up to 6 months or both for first time offenders, and up to $10,000 or imprisonment of up to 12 months or both for subsequent offences.

question: What is the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer: The Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme is a tripartite co-contribution scheme initiated by the National Taxi Association (NTA) and the taxi industry, and supported by the Ministry of Manpower and CPF Board. DAS aims to enhance the welfare of all taxi principal hirers.

question: Who is eligible for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer: Under the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme, all taxi principal hirers who make regular contributions1to their MediSave Account are eligible to receive co-contributions from participating taxi operators. Only contributions that can be used to offset MediSave payable are eligible for DAS co-contributions.If you have outstanding MediSave payable, you may be eligible for DAS co-contributions from participating taxi operators if you make full payment or be on a monthly GIRO instalment plan of at least $20 for your MediSave payable.If you do not have outstanding MediSave payable, you may be eligible for DAS co-contributions from participating taxi operators if you pre-pay your future MediSave payable by contributing at least $20 to your MediSave Account monthly.1You may make MediSave contributions as a self-employed person viaManage your MediSave payableorGIRO.

question: How do I register for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer: No registration is required for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme.Taxi principal hirers who contribute1at least $20 monthly to their MediSave Account will be eligible to receive2a co-contribution of $20 monthly from participating taxi operators.1You may make MediSave contributions as a self-employed person viaManage your MediSave payableorGIRO.2Eligibility for co-contribution is subject to terms and conditions determined by your taxi operator.

question: What sources of MediSave contributions are eligible for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution?
answer: MediSave contributions1made by the taxi principal hirer to offset MediSave payable will qualify him for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution. CPF contributions received as an employee (from both employer and self) for taxi principal hirers who are concurrently employed, as well as government top-ups are excluded.1You may make MediSave contributions as a self-employed person viaManage your MediSave payableorGIRO.

question: Will I receive Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions if I make a lump sum payment?
answer: You will receive Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions of $20 monthly if you have contributed1at least $240 into your MediSave Account in the past 12 months.1You may make MediSave contributions as a self-employed person viaManage your MediSave payableorGIRO.

question: Can taxi principal hirers who are not liable to make a MediSave contribution qualify for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution from their taxi operators?
answer: Taxi principal hirers who do not have outstanding MediSave payable can still receive Drive and Save co-contributions if they make contributions to pre-pay their future MediSave payable1:A contribution of at least $20 to their MediSave Account monthly, orA lump sum MediSave contribution of at least $240 in the past 12 months.1Taxi principal hirers may make MediSave contributions to pre-pay their MediSave payable as self-employed persons viaManage your MediSave payable.

question: How does each taxi operator know the Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution amount?
answer: CPF Board will inform participating taxi operators of taxi principal hirers who qualify1for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions monthly. The amount of contribution made by hirers will not be revealed.Please note that eligibility for co-contribution is subject to terms and conditions determined by taxi operators.1Taxi principal hirers may make MediSave contributions as self-employed persons viaManage your MediSave payableorGIRO.

question: If I participate in the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme, will my Taxi Driver Vocational Licence (TDVL) be automatically renewed?
answer: No, Taxi Driver Vocational Licences (TDVL) will not be automatically renewed upon participation in the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme.Taxi principal hirers must have fully paid their MediSave payable or are making monthly payments via GIRO to renew their TDVLs.MediSave contributions1and co-contributions from taxi operators will offset mandatory MediSave contributions under the Self-Employed Scheme.1Taxi principal hirers may make MediSave contributions as self-employed persons viaManage your MediSave payableorGIRO.

question: How does regular MediSave co-contributions received under the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme benefit me?
answer: Under the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme, the regular MediSave co-contributions from your taxi operator can:Offset your mandatory MediSave contributions under the Self-Employed SchemeEarn up to 6%1interest per annum (p.a.) on your MediSave savings.This includes an additional 1% interest p.a. on the first $60,000 of your combined balances (with up to $20,000 from the Ordinary Account).CPF members aged 55 and above will also earn an additional 1% interest p.a. on the first $30,000 of their combined CPF balances.Pay MediShield Life/Integrated Shield Plan premiums for you and your loved ones (spouse, children, parents, grandparents, or siblings)Qualify2to receive Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payouts in cash and in your MediSave Account1Based on the current 4% interest rate floor for MediSave savings. Refer tocpf.gov.sg/interestratesfor the current rates.2Terms and conditions apply. Refer tocpf.gov.sg/wisfor more information.

question: Can I settle my outstanding MediSave payable by instalments through GIRO?
answer: You can settle your outstanding MediSave payable by instalments through GIRO.If your bank account is withthe participating banks, please complete theSet up GIRO for MediSave contributionsusing your Singpass. You will be re-directed to the bank’s ibanking portal to complete the application. You can check the status of your online application throughmy cpfdigital services - Activitieswith your Singpass.If you wish to use an account from other banks, please download and submit the“Apply for GIRO for MediSave Contributions” (FORM SE GIRO)(PDF, 0.2MB) to the CPF Board. Deduction will be made from the existing bank account until the new GIRO arrangement takes effect.After your GIRO application is approved, we will inform you about your monthly instalment amounts via a notification. You can also view your GIRO instalment plan details via theSelf-employment dashboardafter logging in with your Singpass.If you are facing financial difficulties and need to defer your MediSave contributions, please contact us via ourOnline Enquiry Form.

question: How do I terminate my GIRO arrangement as a self-employed person?
answer: You may submit an online applicationTerminate GIRO for MediSave contributionsusing your Singpass if you wish to terminate your GIRO arrangement as a self-employed person.

question: How do I request an instalment plan for my MediSave contributions?
answer: You can request for an instalment plan for your MediSave contributions via theManage your MediSave payableform.Please note that your request is subject to the Board’s approval. You may be required to provide additional information or supporting documents, if necessary.

question: What is the status of my request to make self-employed MediSave contributions via monthly instalments?
answer: We will keep you informed about the status of your request to make self-employed MediSave contributions via monthly instalments, once it has been processed.Please note our normal processing time:·         Requests made via online appeal: generally 12 working days·         Manual transactions: generally 15 working daysYou can check the status of your request by clicking on thislink.You can view your approved GIRO instalment plan details on theSelf-employment dashboard. To accessmy cpfDigital Services – Self-employment dashboard, please log in to theCPF websiteusing your Singpass.

question: Why was my MediSave instalment amount changed?
answer: The instalment amount for self-employed contributions will change if the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has assessed/reassessed your net trade income.

question: How long does it take to process applications relating to GIRO matters?
answer: Online applications to set up/terminate GIRO for MediSave contributions submitted by the 15thof the month will take effect in the same month. Otherwise, the GIRO arrangement will take effect from the following month.For example, if you submit an online application on 15 June to set up a GIRO arrangement, your first GIRO deduction will take place on *25 June. If you submit the online application on 16 June, your first GIRO deduction will take place on *25 July.Hardcopy applications to set up GIRO arrangement will require up to 21 working days to process. If processed by the 15thof the month, the first GIRO deduction will take place in the same month. Otherwise, the first GIRO deduction will take place from the following month.If you had requested to terminate your GIRO arrangement via your bank, please inform us so that we can update your GIRO details accordingly.*If the 25this a Saturday, Sunday, or Public Holiday, the amount will be deducted on the next working day.

question: How do I change my bank account for GIRO instalments for my MediSave contributions?
answer: If your bank account is withthe participating banks, please complete theSet up GIRO for MediSave contributionsusing your Singpass. You will be re-directed to the bank's ibanking portal to complete the application. You can check the status of your online application throughmy cpfdigital services - Activitieswith your Singpass.If you would like to use an account from other banks, please download and submit theApply for GIRO for MediSave Contributions(FORM SE GIRO) (PDF, 0.2MB) to the Board. Deduction will be made from the existing bank account until the new GIRO arrangement takes effect.

question: What is Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: Under the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme, a MediSave contribution is required as and when a self-employed person (SEP) earns a service fee. Every time a service fee is paid to the SEP, the corporate service buyers (CSBs) or intermediaries making the payment will first deduct and credit a portion of the service fee to the SEP’s MediSave Account, before paying the remainder of the service fee to the SEP.CAYE does not change the amount of MediSave contributions SEPs have to make based on their net trade income.SEPs who provide services to government agencies are automatically enrolled into CAYE.

question: As a self-employed person, how will I benefit from participating in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: Through making smaller and more regular MediSave contributions as and when you receive a service fee, Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) makes saving for your healthcare needs through your MediSave Account (MA) easier. MediSave savings can be used to pay for your out-of-pocket healthcare expenses and MediShield Life premiums.As a self-employed person (SEP), there are many issues that require your attention. CAYE is an easy and hassle-free way to help free up more of your time. For your convenience, your CAYE contributions are automatically deposited into your MA whenever you get paid. This would also be helpful for SEPs whose income may be seasonal. CAYE can also help grow your money as you can start to earn an interest of up to 5% on your MediSave savings earlier.

question: How will participating in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) affect my MediSave contributions payable?
answer: Self-employed persons (SEPs) are required to contribute to their MediSave Account (MA) if their annual Net Trade Income (NTI) is more than $6,000. Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) does not change the amount of MediSave contributions you have to make based on your NTI. The only change concerns how the contributions are made. Under CAYE, the agency/company you provided a service to will help you contribute into your MA each time it makes a service payment to you.Your CAYE contributions are based on your estimated annual revenue and expenses. Thus, CAYE contributions are an estimate of your MediSave payable. After you declare your NTI for the year, your MediSave payable will be computed.If your total Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions are higher than your MediSave payable for the latest year, your excess CAYE contributions will be used to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years1. Any remaining CAYE contributions will then be refunded to you.If your total CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable, you’ll be required to top up the remaining amount. You’ll be notified accordingly, and you can choose to make payment via lump-sum payment(s) or sign up for GIRO instalments.1This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Pleasewrite to usif you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.

question: As a self-employed person, how will the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme affect me?
answer: Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) helps you save for your healthcare needs through smaller and more regular MediSave contributions each time you receive a payment. There is no change to your MediSave contributions payable as it would still be based on your actual Net Trade Income.

question: What if I am in financial hardship and is unable to set aside monies for MediSave via the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme?
answer: We understand that some self-employed persons (SEPs) may be facing financial difficulties and may not be able to cope with Contribute As You Earn (CAYE). Thus, if you do not have outstanding MediSave payable or are contributing via GIRO instalments, you may set your CAYE contribution rate to 0%. This means that you’ll receive your service payment in full, and CAYE contribution will not be deducted from your service payment. Pleasewrite to usif you wish to apply for a 0% CAYE contribution rate. CPF Board will assess your eligibility and inform you of the outcome in writing.

question: Who must participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: SEPs who are individual freelancers or sole proprietors and were awarded jobs with Government agencies will automatically be enrolled into CAYE.Private companies are also encouraged to voluntarily onboard CAYE to help the SEPs who they have contracted with, save for their healthcare and retirement needs in an easier manner.

question: As a self-employed person who provides services to Government agencies, how will I be enrolled into Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: You’ll be automatically enrolled into Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) when you receive a service payment from a Government agency you have provided services to as a self-employed person (SEP). You’ll receive a notification from CPF Board when you receive your first payment via CAYE. Subsequently, you’ll also receive a notification each time you receive a payment via CAYE.

question: I have already contributed up to the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). Why am I still required to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: As a self-employed person, you’re still required to make MediSave contributions even if you have met the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). This is the same for employees.The MediSave amount above the BHS will be transferred to your CPF Special Account (SA)* or Retirement Account (RA). The BHS cap and overflow arrangement are intentionally planned to avoid over savings in MediSave and to supplement your retirement savings. These overflows which end up in your SA or RA can be withdrawn according to thewithdrawal guidelines. If you’ve met the Full Retirement Sum in your SA or RA, the savings in excess of the BHS will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA). Savings in the OA can be used for other purposes such as housing repayment.*The SA will be closed for members aged 55 and above from early 2025. Read morehere.

question: I have contributed up to the maximum mandatory contributions for the year. Do I still have to make Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer: If you’ve made Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions up to the maximum MediSave payable for the year, your applicable CAYE contribution rate will be 0%. This means that you will receive your service fee in full, and CAYE contribution will no longer be deducted from your service fee.However, you’ll still be required to make good your outstanding MediSave payable (if any) via lump-sum payment(s) or GIRO instalment plan.

question: Will self-employed persons who provide services to the private sector be mandated to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: The Government, as a service buyer, has piloted Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) since 1 January 2020. There are currently no plans to extend CAYE into the private sector. Nonetheless, companies in the private sector are encouraged to voluntarily adopt CAYE.

question: What if I prefer making MediSave contributions through the current payment modes (e.g. GIRO)?
answer: The small and regular MediSave contributions made through Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) help self-employed persons (SEPs) to reduce the MediSave contributions payable in the following year (after SEPs declare their Net Trade Income and have their MediSave payable computed).If you’ve made your MediSave contributions in full or are on GIRO instalment plan, you’ll be allowed to set your CAYE contribution rate to 0% and receive your service fee in full.

question: What if I do not wish to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: Self-employed persons (SEPs) who have completed a job with Government agencies will be automatically enrolled into CAYE. CAYE will not apply to SEPs who completed jobs with the private sector.The CAYE scheme helps SEPs save for their healthcare needs through smaller and more regular MediSave contributions each time they receive a service payment. This helps to reduce the MediSave payable in the following year (after SEPs declare their Net Trade Income and have their MediSave payable computed). CAYE will help with the upkeep of current MediSave obligations and prevent snowballing of the payable.You can choose to set your CAYE contribution rate to 0% if you’ve made your MediSave contributions in full or are on GIRO instalment plan.If you’re in financial hardship and unable to set aside monies for your CAYE contributions, you maywrite to us. We will assess your request and inform you of the outcome in writing.

question: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), how much MediSave contribution would I have to make from my service fee?
answer: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), the amount of MediSave contribution deducted from your service fee is based on your estimated annual revenue and expenses for the year.Your CAYE contribution rate is determined by the following formula:CAYE contribution rate =(A x B) / CwhereAis the MediSave contribution rate for your estimated annual Net Trade Income (NTI)1and age for the year;Bis your estimated annual NTI1for the year2; andCis your estimated annual revenue for the year21Your estimated annual NTI is derived using your estimated annual revenue less estimated annual expenses for the year.2If you did not provide your estimated annual revenue and expenses for the year, it will be based on your actual revenue and expenses assessed by IRAS two years ago.A floor CAYE contribution rate of 2% will apply if you have earned more than $6,000 two years ago.To ensure that your CAYE contribution rate reflects your business outlook for the year accurately, please estimate your revenue and expenses by logging in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass, underContribute As You Earn > Update contribution rate. You can adjust your CAYE contribution rate as and when there are changes to your estimated revenue and expenses. Generally, your updated rate will apply to payments made from the next day.Otherwise, a personalised default CAYE contribution rate computed based on your NTI assessed by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) two years ago will apply.Example on how the CAYE contribution rate will be computed

question: How do I estimate my annual revenue and expenses for the year?
answer: You can estimate your annual revenue and expenses for the current year based on the actual revenue and expenses you earned last year. You can adjust your estimated annual revenue and expenses whenever you foresee any changes in revenue (e.g. increase in number of jobs in the current year) or expenses (e.g. increase in business cost, including the cost to engage other to assist in your jobs).

question: How do I adjust my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
answer: If there are changes to your estimated revenue or expenses for the year, you may update and re-compute your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate by logging in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass, underContribute As You Earn > Update contribution rate. Generally, your updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to payments made from the next day.

question: When should I adjust my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
answer: You can adjust your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate by updating your estimated revenue or expense whenever you foresee any changes in revenue (e.g. increase in number of jobs in the current year) or expenses (e.g. increase in business cost, including the cost to engage other to assist in your jobs).

question: I have adjusted my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate. When will the updated rate take effect?
answer: Generally, your updated Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate will apply to service fees paid from the next day.

question: Why are different Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rates applied to different service fees?
answer: Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rates may change when you (i) update your CAYE contribution rate or (ii) are no longer required to make CAYE contributions. Generally, the updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to service fees paid from the next day.

question: Will the estimated income that I have provided for the computation of my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate be used as the income to compute my MediSave payable for the year?
answer: The income information you provided for Contribute As You Earn  (CAYE) is only used to compute the CAYE contribution rate. It will not be used as your actual income to compute your MediSave payable for the year.You’ll still need to declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) or CPF Board the following year. Your MediSave payable for the year will then be computed based on that NTI.

question: Who do I contact for further details on my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee payment amount?
answer: To view your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions and other payment details, you may log in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass, underContribute As You Earn > Show all payments. You can alsocontact us through these channels.For more details on the net service fee, please contact the company or agency you have contracted with directly. If there are any non-payment, short payment or late payment of service fees, you may wish to take up the dispute directly with your buyer and seek mediation through theTripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM)or other industry facilitated mediation services.

question: How does the company I contracted with know my Net Trade Income information and/or Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
answer: The company which you have contracted with will not have access to your Net Trade Income information. CPF Board will only inform the company of the amount that they would have to deduct from your service fee and transmit to your MediSave Account.

question: What should I do if the company I contracted with did not pay my service fees?
answer: For any disputes on non-payment, short payment or late payment of service fees, you may wish to take up the dispute directly with the company or agency you have contracted with and seek mediation through theTripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM)or other industry facilitated mediation services.

question: How do I know if the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution amount and net service fee payment amount are made correctly?
answer: You can check your payment records by logging in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass, underContribute As You Earn > Show all payments.If you’ve previously informed CPF Board of your contact details, you’ll also receive a notification whenever a contribution to your MediSave Account has been made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE). If you wish to update your contact details, you can do so via logging on tomy cpfdigital servicesusing your Singpass.

question: What happens if the MediSave contributions I made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) are higher than my MediSave payable for the year?
answer: If you have outstanding MediSave payable from previous years, your excess CAYE contributions will be used to offset those payables1. Any excess thereafter will be refunded to you. You can also choose to retain the excess CAYE contributions in your MediSave Account (MA).Example:Based on his estimated income of $22,000 for 2023, Sam contributed $2,200 via CAYE. In the following year, he declared that he earned a lower Net Trade Income of $19,000 for 2023. As such, Sam’s MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $1,900. Hence, he has excess CAYE contributions of $300 for the year. Sam also has an outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022 which would be offset by the excess CAYE contributions, leaving a final excess amount of $200. This amount will be refunded to him2. He can also choose to keep this $200 in his MA.This example is illustrated within the table below:Estimated 2023 NTI$22,000CAYE contributions in 2023$2,200(After 2023 NTI declaration)Declared 2023 NTI$19,000MediSave payable for work done in 2023$1,900Outstanding MediSave payable for 2022$100Amount Sam will receive as a refund$200(i.e. $2,200 - $1,900 - $100)1This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Pleasewrite to usif you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.2Sam may also choose not to use his CAYE contributions to offset his outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022. In this case, he will be refunded $300 instead.

question: What happens if the MediSave contributions I made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) are lower than my MediSave payable for the year?
answer: If your total CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable for the latest year, you will be required to top up the remaining amount. You’ll be notified accordingly, and you can choose to make payment via a lump-sum payment(s) or sign up for monthly GIRO instalments.Example:Based on his estimated income of $21,000 for 2023, Sam contributed $2,100 via CAYE. In the following year, he declared that he earned a higher NTI of $30,000 for 2023. As such, Sam’s MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $3,000. Sam will have to top up the shortfall of $900.This example is illustrated within the table below:Estimated 2023 NTI$21,000CAYE contributions in 2023$2,100(After 2023 NTI declaration)Declared 2023 NTI$30,000MediSave payable for work done in 2023$3,000Shortfall Sam has to top up$900(i.e. $3,000 - $2,100)

question: Will I get into trouble if my actual income declared to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board in the following year is different from the income estimated on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services?
answer: No, as the revenue and expenses information on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services is an estimate of your business outlook for the year. You are still required to declare your actual Net Trade Income to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board to compute your MediSave payable for the year.

question: Why do I still have outstanding MediSave payable when I am already on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: Your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions is an estimate of your MediSave payable for the year and may be lower or higher than your MediSave payable for the year. If your CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable for the year, you’ll be required to top up the shortfall. You’ll also be required to make MediSave contributions for any outstanding MediSave payable incurred in previous years.

question: Can I choose to retain my excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions in my MediSave Account?
answer: Yes, you can choose to retain your excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions in your MediSave Account. You may apply to do so by logging in to theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass.

question: Can I use my excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions to offset my outstanding MediSave payable?
answer: CAYE contributions in excess of your MediSave payable for the year will be automatically used to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years, if any1. Any excess thereafter will be refunded to your bank account.You can also choose to boost your healthcare savings by retaining the excess CAYE contributions in your MediSave Account to earn up to 5% interest per annum, and to offset future MediSave payable. To do so, please apply via theSelf-employment dashboardusing your Singpass.1This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Pleasewrite to usif you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.

question: Why do I still need to declare my income to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board when I have already done so on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services?
answer: The revenue and expenses information on the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services is an estimate of your business outlook for the year and used only to compute your CAYE contribution rate. It is not a declaration of your actual Net Trade Income (NTI) and you are still required to declare your actual NTI in the following year to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) / CPF Board to compute your mandatory MediSave payable.

question: Can I renew my licence if I have been making Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer: You can renew your licence so long as you have no outstanding MediSave payable or are on a monthly GIRO instalment plan.

question: Why do I need to make other payment arrangements in order to renew my licence when I am already on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
answer: Your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions are only based on an estimate of your MediSave payable for the current year. To renew your licence, you will need to pay your MediSave payable incurred in previous years via lump-sum payment(s) or monthly GIRO instalments.

question: Where can I find guides on how to make Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) transactions?
answer: If you need assistance on how to make Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) transactions, you can refer to theCAYE step-by-step guide, or you canwrite to us.

question: Does Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions qualify for tax relief?
answer: Similar to other forms of self-employed CPF contributions, Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions will qualify for tax relief based on the date of payment. CAYE contributions made in a calendar year will qualify for tax relief in the following year. For example, relief on CAYE contributions made between 1 January 2024 and 31 December 2024 will qualify for tax relief in the Year of Assessment (YA) 2025 subject to the assessable net trade income (NTI) for this YA.The CPF relief allowable to self-employed persons (SEPs) for his MediSave and voluntary CPF contributions, including CAYE contributions, will be capped at 37% of his NTI assessed or CPF relief cap of $37,740 or the actual amount contributed by SEP whichever is the lowest. There is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.

question: How will the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme affect my income declaration to IRAS for tax purposes?
answer: There will be no change to Self-Employed Person (SEP)’s declaration of income for tax purposes. SEPs should continue to declare his annual income earned up to 31stDecember of the preceding year in the Income Tax Return for the current Year of Assessment (YA). For example, the SEP needs to declare his gross income for services provided between 1 January 2024 and 31 December 2024 in Income Tax Return for YA2025, even if it is invoiced only in January 2025. This is regardless of when the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions for the said services are made.

question: Why can't I find the bank account input details on Vendors@Gov?
answer: From early June 2024, you will only be able to select PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) as the mode of payment.

question: Can I choose to continue to submit my bank account details to receive payments for government service instead of PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address), and what do I need to do to ensure I can continue to receive my service fee payments?
answer: You will only be able to use the bank account registered to your PayNow to receive service fee payments.Please ensure that you have registered for PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) so that you receive your service fee payments promptly. If not, you will not be able to receive your service fee payments from early June 2024.We encourage you to check with your bank to ensure your details are updated or if you need more information on how to sign up for PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address).

question: Why is PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) the default mode of bank payments moving forward?
answer: PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) aligns with the government's drive for digital transformation and the Smart Nation initiative, as it promotes the adoption of digital payment. It also provides citizens a more secured mode of payment as they do not need to provide their bank account details to receive their service fee payments.

question: When will I need to be registered for PayNow to continue receiving my net service fee payments without delay?
answer: PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) will be the default payment mode from early June 2024. Please ensure that you are registered for PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) so that you receive your service fee payments promptly.

question: What are the CPF interest rates?
answer: CPF Interest Rates (1 January 2025 to 31 March 2025)Ordinary AccountSpecial, MediSave and Retirement AccountInterest Rate2.5%4%To help boost retirement savings, the Government pays extra interest on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances, which is capped at $20,000 for Ordinary Account (OA). Please refer to details on extra interest in the table below.AgeExtra interestBelow 55 years old1% per annum on the first $60,000 (capped at $20,000 for OA)55 years old and above2% per annum on the first $30,000, 1% per annum on the next $30,000(capped at $20,000 for OA)Extra interest earned on OA savings go into your Special Account (SA) or Retirement Account (RA) to enhance your retirement savings. If you are participating in the CPF LIFE scheme, you will still earn the extra interest on your combined CPF balances, including the savings used for CPF LIFE.Please refer to the respective links for more information on theCPF interest ratesandhistorical CPF interest rates(PDF, 0.15MB).

question: How are CPF interest rates determined?
answer: Savings in the Ordinary Account (OA) earn the 3-month average of major local banks’ interest rates, subject to the legislated minimum interest of 2.5% per annum. This is reviewed quarterly.Savings in the Special, MediSave and Retirement Account (SMRA) earn the 12-month average yield of 10-year Singapore Government Securities (10YSGS) plus 1%, subject to the current floor interest rate of 4% per annum. This is reviewed quarterly.Please refer to theCPF interest ratesandMOF websitefor more information.Computation of CPF OA Interest Rate and HDB Mortgage Rate for1 January 2025 to 31 March 2025Average banks' interest rate from August 2024 to October 20240.45% (see note)CPF OA interest rate for January 2025 to March 20252.50% per annum(legislated minimum rate)Plus:Fee to cover Cost of Loan Administration0.10%HDB mortgage rate for January 2025 to March 20252.60% per annumNote:12-month deposit rate(% per annum)Savings Rate(% per annum)Average(% per annum)Month / YearDBS1OCBC2UOB3DBS4OCBC5UOB6Using the 80FD:20SD formula31 Aug 20240.05000.10001.50000.05000.05000.05000.450030 Sep 20240.05000.10001.50000.05000.05000.05000.450031 Oct 20240.05000.10001.50000.05000.05000.05000.45001Balances of $20,000 to < $50,0002Balances > $20,000 to $50,0003Balances < $50,0004Balances > $10,000 to $100,000 (AUTO-SAVE Account)5Entire Account Balance (EASI-SAVE Account)6Balances > $15,000 to $100,000 (UNIPLUS Account)Computation of CPF SMRA Interest Rate for1 January 2025 to 31 March 2025Average yield of 10YSGS from November 2023 to October 20242.99%Plus: 1.00%1.00%Computed CPF SMRA interest rate for January 2025 to March 20253.99%CPF SMRA interest rate floor for January 2025 to March 20254.00%CPF SMRA interest rate for January 2025 to March 20254.00% per annumSource: Yields of 10-Year Singapore Government Securities are obtained frommas.gov.sg/bonds-and-bills

question: How much extra interest can I earn on my CPF savings?
answer: To help boost retirement savings, the Government pays extra interest on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances, which is capped at $20,000 for Ordinary Account (OA). Extra interest is structured so that all CPF members benefit, and members with lower balances benefit more. The amount of extra interest paid to you would depend on your combined CPF balances and age.If you are below 55 years old, you will earn an extra interest of 1% per annum on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances (capped at $20,000 for OA). The extra interest earned on your Special Account (SA) and MediSave Account (MA) balances will go to the respective accounts, while the extra interest earned on your OA balances will go into your SA to enhance your retirement savings.If you are 55 years old and above, you will earn an extra interest of 2% per annum on the first $30,000 and 1% per annum on the next $30,000 of your combined CPF balances (capped at $20,000 for OA). The extra interest earned on your Retirement Account (RA), SA and MA balances will go to the respective accounts, while the extra interest earned on your OA balances will go into your RA to enhance your retirement savings. If you have joined the CPF LIFE scheme, the extra interest earned will be paid into your RA or accumulated with the interest earned on the CPF LIFE premiums of all CPF LIFE members.How is my combined CPF balance computed?Your accounts are used to compute your combined CPF balances in the following order:- 1st: Retirement Account (RA), including any CPF LIFE premium balance- 2nd: OA, with a cap of $20,000*- 3rd: Special Account (SA)- 4th: MediSave Account (MA)*A cap of $20,000 from OA is imposed because OA savings are short-term in nature and can be withdrawn on demand for a few purposes such as housing and education.

question: How is my CPF interest computed and credited into my accounts?
answer: CPF interest is computed monthly. It is credited to your respective accounts by the following year and compounded annually.CPF balances used for interest computation are affected by the transactions in your account. For instance, contributions (including refunds) received this month start earning interest next month. Withdrawals/deductions in this month will not earn interest from this month onwards.There are strict procedures in place to ensure the accuracy of members’ CPF accounts and transactions (including interest payments). To further ensure that our system is sound and robust, our statutory auditor performs regular reviews of formulas and computations in our systems for accuracy, and conducts independent verifications of the transactions and account balances.

question: Will the interest rates on savings in the Special, MediSave and Retirement Account be maintained at a floor rate?
answer: To help CPF members grow their savings, the Government has decided to further extend the 4% floor rate for interest earned on all Special, MediSave and Retirement Account (SMRA) savings for another year until 31 December 2025.SMRA savings will earn a minimum 4% interest rate per annum until 31 December 2025.Please refer to our FAQ onhow CPF interest rates are determinedfor more information.

question: What should I know about topping up my retirement savings?
answer: Here are the 3 things you need to know about topping up your retirement savings. Tax relief is subject toterms and conditions..

question: Why should I top up my retirement savings?
answer: There are several reasons why you should consider topping up your retirement savings:1. Higher monthly payouts in retirementBy topping up your Special Account (SA) (if you are below 55) or Retirement Account (RA) (if you are 55 or above), you are growing your retirement savings and will enjoyhigher monthly payoutswhen you retire.2. Risk-free interest rates* of up to 6% per annumBy topping up your SA or RA, you can earn risk-freeinterest rates* of up to 6% per annumon your savings.For instance, if you save $100 a month for 15 years on your own, you would have saved $18,000. On the other hand, if you top up $100 a month to your SA or RA for the same amount of time, you would have saved over $24,000*. If you continue to top up for another 10 years, your savings would grow even more, reaching over $50,000* with compound interest.3. Enjoy tax relief and matching grant for cash top-upsBy topping up with cash, you can also benefit from:Tax relief of up to $16,000.Terms and conditions apply.Matching dollar-for-dollar grant from the Government if you are eligible for theMatched Retirement Savings Scheme.Terms and conditions apply.*Based on the current 4%interest ratefloor on Special and Retirement Account monies.

question: How will the top-ups to my retirement savings be used?
answer: Top-up monies will form part of yourretirement sumand give youhigher monthly payouts in retirement. As such, top-up monies cannot be withdrawn as a lump sum, withdrawn from your Retirement Account savings using property, or transferred to your loved ones.Additionally, top-up monies cannot be used for other CPF schemes, such aswithdrawal for immediate retirement needs,withdrawal on exemption from setting aside a retirement sum, and other CPF schemes for education, investment, insurance, housing etc.

question: Can I top up using cash or CPF transfers?
answer: Yes, you can top up your retirement savings using cash or by making CPF transfers. Please take note thatCPF transfers do not qualify for tax relieformatching grant from the government under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme.If you wish to increase your own or your loved ones' retirement savings, you can find out more here:Who you can make top-ups toWho you can receive top-ups fromHow much you can top up via cashHow much you can top up via CPF transfer

question: Who can I make top-ups to?
answer: Cash top-upsYou can make cash top-ups to any Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident.Find out the amount of cash top-ups you can make to a recipient.CPF transfersYou can only make CPF transfers to yourself or yourloved ones. CPF transfers can only be made to a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident.Find out the amount of CPF transfers you can make to yourself or your loved ones.

question: Who can I receive top-ups from?
answer: Cash top-upsYou can receive cash top-ups from anyone, including yourself, your family, employers, platform operators or any member of the community.CPF transfersYou can receive CPF transfers only from yourself or yourloved ones.You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident to receive a top-up.

question: Who are considered my loved ones?
answer: Your loved ones refer to your parents, parents-in-law, grandparents, grandparents-in-law, spouse and siblings.

question: Is there a minimum or maximum age for making or receiving top-ups?
answer: There is no maximum age for making or receiving top-ups.However, you will need to be at least 16 years old to be a giver of cash top-ups.You can make cash top-ups to a child who is not yet 16 years old, and you can find out how to do sohere.

question: Can I still receive top-ups if I have started my monthly retirement payouts?
answer: Yes, you can receive top-ups as long as you have not reached thecurrent Enhanced Retirement Sum.Find outhow much top-ups you can receive.

question: What are the differences between topping up my retirement savings, making a Voluntary Housing Refund and topping up my MediSave Account?
answer: Find out what the differences between the various types of top-ups are below:Topping up your retirement savingsVoluntary Housing RefundTopping up your MediSave AccountTop up/refund toSpecial Account (SA) for members below 55; orRetirement Account (RA) for members 55 or above.Ordinary Account (OA); and/orRA for members 55 or above and have not met their Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in their RA.MediSave Account (MA)Eligibility for tax reliefYou can enjoy tax relief if you madecash top-ups to yourself or your loved ones up to the current FRS.However, please note that tax relief would not apply if you made a CPF transfer.You will not be eligible for tax relief.For non self-employed persons:You get to enjoytax relieffor voluntary top-ups to MA.If you are self-employed, you will enjoytax reliefon yourMediSave contributionsbased on your annual net trade income (NTI). There will be no tax relief for your MediSave contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.Top-up limitWhat is the maximum amount of top-ups I can receive?If you are below 55, you may top up your SA up to the current FRS.If you are 55 or above, you may top up your RA up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum.You can check your top-up limit in yourRetirement Dashboard.Can I voluntarily refund a portion of the CPF savings I used for my property?You can make a refund of any amount, capped at the full principal amount you have withdrawn for the property, along with the accrued interest.You may check the amount that you can refund through theHome Ownership Dashboard.Do note that after making a full voluntary housing refund of the CPF savings withdrawn and accrued interest, all CPF withdrawals including monthly housing loan instalments (if any) for the property will stop.What is the voluntary top-up limit to my MediSave Account?The maximum amount you can voluntarily top up to your MA is the difference between yourBasic Healthcare Sum (BHS)and your current MA balance. Once your BHS has been reached, no further voluntary top-ups can be made to your MA. If you exceed your BHS from the top-up, the full amount of your top-up will be refunded to you.You can check your top-up limitwith these steps.WithdrawalTop-ups are meant to boost your retirement income.
