They will be streamed out to you as monthly payouts and cannot be used for other purposes.You can continue to use your OA savings for the current or next property after making a voluntary housing refund.However, if you would like to use your OA for the same property, after making a voluntary refund of the full principal amount used and the accrued interest, you will need to re-apply to use your CPF savings.After turning 55 and setting aside the FRS, you can withdraw the remaining balance in your OA and SA in full or in part at any time.From 55, you can make retirement withdrawals from your OA and SA in full or in part, at any time for your immediate needs, provided you have set aside your FRS.MA savings are meant for your healthcare needs and cannot be withdrawn as cash.ApplicationTop-ups can be made using cash and/or CPF transfers.How do I apply to make a top-up?Refund can only be made via cash.How can I make a voluntary refund of the housing amount withdrawn if I am not selling my property?Top-ups can only be made via cash.How can I top up to myself, my children or my loved ones’ MediSave Account?Click thislinkto find out what the CPF interest rates are.

question: I received an email notification on topping up my and/or my loved ones’ retirement savings. How do I know if the notification is indeed sent by CPF Board?
answer: Members will receive email notifications at the email address registered with the Board. You maycheck or update your email addresswhich you have earlier registered with us using your Singpass.To verify if the email you received is legitimate andavoid falling prey to phishing scams,Ensure that the sender's email address is correctly spelt and ends with "@e.cpf.gov.sg".Ensure that the hyperlinks or links you click on has a domain ending with “.gov.sg”.

question: When will the top-ups received in my CPF Special/Retirement Account start to earn interest?
answer: If you receive a cash top-up this month, it will start earning interest in the next month.For CPF transfers of existing CPF savings, you will start earning interest in your account from this month. However, if the CPF savings are fresh injections, it will start earning interest in your account from the next month.

question: If I am 55 and would like to make a CPF transfer, in what order will my savings be transferred?
answer: CPF transfers to your Retirement Account (RA)If you are 55 or above, your CPF savings will be transferred to your RA in the following order:Special Account (SA)Ordinary Account (OA)CPF transfers to yourloved onesIf you are 55 or above, your CPF savings will betransferred to your loved onesin the following order:OASARA**If you use your RA savings for the transfer, you may no longer have enough savings to meet your Full Retirement Sum (FRS). In that case, the next time you apply for a withdrawal from your OA and SA, a portion or all of the savings will be used to meet your FRS in the RA.

question: I am 55, can I transfer my Ordinary Account savings to my Special Account to earn a higher interest rate?
answer: No, you will not be able to make CPF transfers to your Special Account (SA) after you turn 55. Instead, your transfers will be made to your Retirement Account (RA), which was created for your retirement needs.Did you know?If you wish to earn higherintereston your Ordinary Account (OA) savings (which earns at least 2.5% interest* per annum) and boost your monthly payouts, you canmake a CPF transferto your RA (which earns at least 4% interest* per annum), up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum. Do note that for CPF transfers to RA, your SA savings (if any) will be transferred first followed by your OA savings.* Based on the current interest rate floor on Ordinary and Retirement Account monies.

question: Why am I not allowed to transfer my CPF savings to my children?
answer: Your CPF savings are meant to support your retirement needs. Your children would be able to accumulate savings in their working years. Hence, it is more important to prioritise your own retirement savings and ensure that you have sufficient funds to support your retirement needs.Find outhow you can use cash to top up your child's CPF account.

question: Why am I not allowed to do a CPF transfer to my extended family members (e.g. uncles/aunts/cousins)?
answer: The CPF system is meant to provide for and safeguard your individual retirement adequacy. Hence we must be careful when considering allowing CPF transfers to extended family members, beyond immediate family members such as your parents, spouse and siblings. Meanwhile, you can consider using cash to top up to your extended family member's CPF account instead.

question: If I wish to make both a CPF transfer and a cash top-up to myself / my loved one, which should I do first?
answer: If you wish to enjoy tax relief on your cash top-up to help you or your loved one up to the Full Retirement Sum, please make the cash top-up first, before the CPF transfer. If you prefer using your CPF savings over cash, please make the CPF transfer first.You may wish to take note that only cash top-ups to self and loved ones within the Full Retirement Sum can enjoy tax relief. Learn more abouttax relief.

question: When is the best time to top up to grow my savings?
answer: You should top up as early as possible to maximise the growth of your CPF savings through the power of compound interest.Additionally, you can earn more interest if you top up earlier in the year. For example, if you top up in January each year instead of in December, you can earn up to 20%* more interest on your top-ups in 10 years.* Based on the current 4%interest ratefloor on Special and Retirement Account monies and extra interest of up to 2% per annum on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances, with $8,000 annual top-up and $0 starting balance.Do top up early in the year to ensure that your top-ups are processed before the year end as the normal processing time may take longer in December if there is a surge in applications.

question: How can I check my top-up limits?
answer: You can check your top-up limit in yourRetirement Dashboard.Find outhow the top up limit is computed.

question: What is the maximum amount of top-ups I can receive?
answer: The maximum amount of top-ups you can receive depends on your age and amount of CPF savings you have. You can easily check your top-up limit in yourRetirement Dashboard.You can refer to theseexampleson how the maximum top-up amount is computed.

question: Why am I not able to top up my Special/Retirement Account beyond the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) (below 55) or Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) (55 or above)?
answer: The CPF system is designed to cater to the basic retirement needs of the broad majority of Singaporeans.If you are below 55, you can top up your Special Account up to the current year’s Full Retirement Sum (FRS) to build up your retirement savings. If you wish to save beyond the FRS, you can choose to tap on theSupplementary Retirement Scheme, where contributions are also eligible for tax relief.If you are 55 or above, retirement becomes a higher priority. As such, members have the option to voluntarily top up beyond the FRS up to thecurrent year’s Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)for higher payouts. This could help the middle-income group better meet their retirement needs.Find out more aboutwhat the retirement sums are.

question: How much CPF savings can I transfer to myself or my loved ones?
answer: You can easily check the maximum amount of CPF savings you can transfer in yourRetirement Dashboard.If you would like to learn more about how the amount shown on your Retirement Dashboard is If you have set aside the BRS and own a property bought using CPF savings, the P+I can be considered towards meeting the FRS for making CPF transfers to your parents and/or grandparents. If you have pledged your property for purposes of setting aside part of your retirement sum or to withdraw your retirement savings, the amount secured by the property can be considered towards meeting the FRS for this CPF transfer.

question: Is there a limit to the number of top-ups I can make or receive in a year?
answer: There is no limit to the number of top-ups you can make or receiveas long as the recipient can still receive top-ups.It is important to note that once you make a top-up, it cannot be reversed. Therefore, we advise you to review that you have sufficient cash or CPF savings for other expenses before making the top-up.

question: Can I top up my retirement savings to the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)?
answer: If you are aged 55 or above, you have the option to top up your Retirement Account (RA) up to thecurrent year’s Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)as retirement becomes an even higher priority.If you are aged below 55, you can start building up more retirement savings by topping up your Special Account up to thecurrent year’s Full Retirement Sum (FRS). Once you reach age 55, you can then choose to set aside more in your RA, up to the current year’s ERS.You can check your top-up limit on yourRetirement Dashboard.

question: What is the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)?
answer: The Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) in 2025 is $426,000. This is the maximum amount that members aged 55 and above can top up their Retirement Accounts (RA) to in 2025. From 1 January 2025, the ERS amount is 4 times of the current year’s Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) and provides members the option to top up more for higher payouts.The ERS amount is not dependent on your age or the year you turn 55 years old. It increases yearly on 1 January. Here are the ERS amounts for 2025 to 2027:Year202520262027Enhanced Retirement Sum$426,000$440,800$456,400You can top up more to your RA every year when the ERS increases. To illustrate, a member aged 55 and above in 2025 would be able to top up to $426,000. In 2026, when the ERS is increased to $440,800 the member will be able to top up a further $14,800 (i.e. $440,800 - $426,000).You can top up your RA with cash or your Ordinary Account (OA) and Special Account (SA) savings. Topping up your RA allows you to receive higher monthly payouts in retirement. This allows members to get higher CPF LIFE monthly payouts of up to $3,300 for life from age 65 through CPF top-ups.Learn more about the payouts you can receive if you top up to the ERS.You may check the maximum amount you can top up on yourRetirement Dashboard.

question: Am I eligible for tax reliefs when I make a cash top-up to my/my loved ones' retirement savings?
answer: You can enjoy tax relief if you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident and make cash top-ups*within the current year’s Full Retirement Sum for yourself, yourloved ones, employees or platform workers.Find out more aboutthe amount of tax relief you can enjoy.Find out more on theconditions to qualify for tax relief.*From 1 January 2025, givers of cash top-ups that attract the matching grant (up to $2,000 per year) under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) will no longer receive tax relief. Find out more onhow this works.

question: How much tax relief can I enjoy when I make cash top-ups?
answer: You can enjoy an equivalent amount of tax relief for cash top-ups made in each calendar year of up to:$8,000 if you make a top-up to yourself; andan additional $8,000 if you make a cash top-up to yourloved ones.Please note that only cash top-ups up to the current year’s Full Retirement Sum (FRS) are eligible for tax relief.Log in with your Singpassto find out how much you can top up to yourself. If you make cash top-ups to your loved ones, please note that the tax relief does not apply to your recipients. Find out theconditions to qualify for tax relief.If your employer or platform operator made a cash top-up on your behalf, you could receive up to $8,000* of tax relief per calendar year. If you are an employer or platform operator making cash top-ups to your employees' or platform workers’ Special/ Retirement accounts, youmay claim tax deduction on the cash top-ups when filing your company’s income tax return.* Includes any tax relief that the employee or platform worker would enjoy for cash top-ups made to himself.From 1 January 2025, givers of cash top-ups that attract the matching grant (up to $2,000 per year) under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) will no longer receive tax relief. Find out more onhow this works.

question: What are the conditions for me to enjoy tax relief?
answer: The conditions for you to enjoy tax relief when you make cash top-ups to yourself, your loved ones, employees or platform workers are as follows:You can enjoy tax relief of up to $8,000 if you make a top-up to yourself; and an additional $8,000 if you make a cash top-up to yourloved ones.For cash top-ups to self and your loved ones, tax relief is only up to the current year’s Full Retirement Sum (FRS).Log in with your Singpassto see how much you can top up to yourself.There is a personal income tax relief cap of $80,000, which applies to all tax reliefs, including tax relief on cash top-ups made to your CPF accounts.The tax relief cap will be shared for cash top-ups to Special Account (SA)/Retirement Account (RA) and/or cash top-ups to MediSave Account (MA) *. Find out more aboutthe amount of tax relief you can enjoy.If you make cash top-ups to your loved ones, please note that tax relief does not apply to your recipients.Your loved ones include parents, parents-in-law, grandparents, grandparents-in-law, spouse and siblings.If you are making cash top-ups to a spouse or sibling, you will only be eligible for the tax relief if the recipient's income in the previous year does not exceed $8,000 or if the recipient is handicapped^. In this instance, income would include income from bank interest, dividend and pension, investment income/rental income/directorship income. An example of a handicapped person is someone with visual-impairment, loss of hearing, loss of limb and dementia.If you are making a cash top-up to the SA/RA of your employee or platform worker on his behalf, you will be eligible for an equivalent amount of tax deductions for the cash top-ups made. While such a cash top-up will be included in your employee or platform worker's taxable income, your employee or platform worker will receive tax relief of up to $8,000 for cash top-ups made in each calendar year. The tax relief that your employee or platform worker will receive also takes into consideration any cash top-ups that he has made to his own SA/RA and MA.If you would like to make a CPF contribution to your employee or platform worker’s MA as an employer or platform operator, please do so under the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme (AMCS) to be eligible for tax deduction on your contribution. AMCS contributions are tax-free for employees and platform workers.From 1 January 2025, givers of cash top-ups that attract the matching grant (up to $2,000 per year) under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) will no longer receive tax relief. Find out more onhow this works.You can learn more abouttax relief.*The changes related to cash top-ups to MA do not apply to MA contributions made in the capacity of a self-employed person (SEP). If you would like to make MA contributions in the capacity of a SEP, visit theSelf-Employed Scheme pagefor more information on topping up your MA.^This refers to people who are incapacitated because of physical or mental infirmity.

question: Why is there a combined tax relief cap for top-ups to the Special Account/Retirement Account and MediSave Account from 1 January 2022?
answer: Thecombined tax relieffor cash top-ups to the Special/Retirement Account and MediSave Account (MA) was introduced for greater consistency across CPF schemes. This allows members to better understand and take action to benefit from these schemes.The tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups made before 1 January 2022 had differed1for top-ups to retirement savings and top-ups to MA. With this change2, the tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups made on or after 1 January 2022 across both schemes have been aligned.1Before 1 January 2022, the tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups differed between both scheme in terms of (i) tax beneficiary [giver for Retirement Sum Topping-Up (RSTU); recipient for Voluntary Contribution to MediSave Account (VCMA)]; and (ii) tax relief cap for top-ups to self/loved ones (capped at $7k/$7k for RSTU, tax relief cap for VCMA depended on both the Basic Healthcare Sum and the amount of mandatory CPF contributions for the year).2The changes related to cash top-ups to MA do not apply to MA contributions made as a self-employed person (SEP). If you would like to make MA contributions as a SEP, visit theSelf-Employed Scheme pagefor more information on topping up your MA.

question: When should I submit my top-up application if I want to be eligible for tax relief in the next assessment year?
answer: Your online top-up application and payment will need to reach us by 31 December of the year.It is important to note that the tax relief is granted based on the calendar year in which the top-up is made, regardless of the actual date of submission.We would also encourage you to top up earlier in the year. Find outwhy you should top up as early as possible.

question: What actions do I need to take to file and claim tax relief for my cash top-up?
answer: You do not need to file or claim tax relief for your cash top-up as we will automatically inform Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) if you have instructed to claim tax relief in your top-up application and are eligible.If you made a cash top-up to your spouse and/or sibling between 1 January 2024 and 16 February 2024 and wish to amend your instructions to claim tax relief for the top-up made due to the increase in income threshold from $4,000 to $8,000, you can refer tothis FAQ.Please note that only givers who make cash top-ups are eligible for tax relief. If you make cash top-ups to your loved ones, the tax relief does not apply to your receipients. Find outthe conditions to enjoy tax relief.

question: What is the personal income tax relief cap and why is there a cap on this relief for cash top-ups made?
answer: Thepersonal income tax relief capsets a limit on the total amount of tax relief you can claim.Even though each relief serves a good purpose, some individuals may end up with a significantly reduced taxable income when multiple reliefs are combined. Therefore, tax relief on cash top-ups is also subjected to the personal income tax relief cap.

question: How can I find out if I have reached the personal income tax relief cap?
answer: You can use thetax calculatoron Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website to find out if you have reached your personal income tax relief cap.

question: Why is there no tax relief for top-ups made to my children or non-immediate family?
answer: Tax relief is an incentive given to encourage members to build up retirement savings for themselves or their immediate family members, particularly older Singaporeans who may have less retirement savings.Your children have more time to accumulate savings in their working years for their own retirement needs. Hence, there is no tax relief for top-ups made to your children or non-immediate family members.

question: Why are CPF transfers not eligible for tax relief?
answer: CPF contributions are tax-deductible. Therefore, when they are transferred from one CPF account to another, they will not enjoy tax benefits.Considertopping up using cashto enjoy tax relief while boosting your retirement payouts. Find outthe conditions to enjoy tax relief.

question: Why are cash top-ups beyond Full Retirement Sum not eligible for tax relief?
answer: Givers enjoy tax relief for cash top-ups up to the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS). This is in line with the intent of tax relief benefits to encourage cash top-ups to members with lower to average CPF retirement balances.

question: I am an employer or platform operator who made cash top-ups to my employees or platform workers’ CPF Accounts on their behalf. How do I claim corporate tax deductions?
answer: Cash top-ups made to your employees or platform workers’ CPF Retirement Accounts/ Special Accounts, on the employees or platform workers’ behalf, are tax-deductible. You are able to claim tax deduction on the cash top-ups as part of your allowable business expenses when filing the income tax return (Form B) for self-employed person or (Form C-S/ Form C-S (Lite)/ Form C) for company.For more information, you may refer to the IRAS website onTop-Up of Employees’ CPF RetirementAccounts/ Special Accounts/ MediSave Accounts.

question: How do I apply to make a top-up?
answer: To make a top-up,you can refer to the following table:Application modePayment viaGuideWebRecurring cash top-upsvia GIROGuideOne-time cash top-upvia PayNow QRGuide(PDF, 0.1MB)Video GuideCPF transferGuideCPF Mobile appPayNow QROCBC DigitalEnglishChineseMalayTamilCPF transferGuideEmployers or platform operators who wish to make cash top-ups for their employees or platform workers canapply onlineusingCorppass. If you do not have Corppass, you maywrite to usfor an alternate application mode.* If you are making afirst-timeCPF transfer to your loved ones, find out thesupporting documents that you need to submit.

question: How long does it take to process my top-up application?
answer: Please refer to the table for our normal processing time for processing top-up applications:Top-Up ViaPayment ModeNormal Processing timeProcessingDeduction and CreditingCashPayNow QROCBC DigitalAlmost instantlyOnline GIRO (participatingbankusers)Upon successful application to set up GIRO to make cash top-ups, please allowone day for your GIRO bank account to be updated in the Board's record.GIRO deduction will take effect from the following month upon successful application of your recurring cash top-ups.If you are updating your GIRO bank account,find out more on the GIRO deduction for your existing recurring top-up arrangements.We will deduct the monies from your bank account on the 15thof the month (or the next working day if 15thfalls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday).Your top-up will be credited within seven working days after we receive your payment.Note: Please ensure that you maintain sufficient funds in your bank account for GIRO deductions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for each unsuccessful deduction.CPF Transfer-Five working days upon receipt of applicationIn some cases, we may require additional time to verify your application. We will contact you within five working days to request for more information.

question: When should I submit my application for my top-up to be processed within the same month?
answer: If you are making a cash top-upBoth your application and payment should be made by the following timings:Payment modeWhen payment should be madePayNow QRWithin last day of the monthOCBC Digital (available for applications via CPF Mobile app only)Online GIROYour GIRO instruction will take effect in the same month If you submitboth:GIRO application; andStanding Instructionwithin the first seven days of the month.To have your cash top-up processed quickly, we encourage payment via PayNow QR or OCBC Digital. Your cash top-up will generally be creditedalmost instantlyupon successful payment.If you are making a CPF transferYou should submit your application before the 5thlast working day of the month.

question: What is the fastest way to make a cash top-up?
answer: The fastest way to make a cash top-up would be via PayNow QR or OCBC Digital (for applications via CPF Mobile app oronline form). Your cash top-up will generally be creditedalmost instantlyupon successful payment.

question: How can I apply for internet or mobile banking?
answer: Applying for internet or mobile banking is easy and convenient. To get started, you can refer to thedigital banking resourcescompiled by Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA). This list provides a comprehensive guide on how to apply for internet or mobile banking with various banks in Singapore.You can also visit anySG Digital community hubto enjoy one-on-one guidance from IMDA’s digital ambassadors, who would be happy to assist you in setting up your internet or mobile banking account and answer any questions you may have.

question: How can I increase my internet or mobile banking transfer limit?
answer: You can increase your internet or mobile banking transfer limit via your bank’s internet or mobile banking portal. Please refer to the guides below:Payment via PayNow:1.POSB/DBS– DigibankLanguageEnglishChineseMalayTamil2.UOB– UOB TMRWLanguageEnglishChineseMalayTamil3.OCBC– OCBC DigitalLanguageEnglishChineseMalayTamil4.Standard Chartered5.HSBC6.Maybank7.CitibankYou may also wish to refer to the list ofPayNow participating banks.

question: What supporting documents will I need if I'm making a first-time CPF transfer to my loved ones?
answer: For first-time CPF transfers to your loved ones, you will need to submit the following supporting documents in the top-up application.CPF transfer toSupporting documentsSpouseMarriage certificate, if your marriage is registered overseasParent(s)Your birth certificateGrandparent(s)Your and your parent(s)’s birth certificatesSibling(s)Your and your sibling(s)’s birth certificatesParent(s)-in-lawYour overseas marriage certificate* and your spouse’s birth certificate.Grandparent(s)-in-lawYour overseas marriage certificate, your spouse’s and your spouse’s parent(s)’s birth certificates*Not required if your marriage is registered in SingaporeSupporting documents are not required for cash top-ups.

question: How can I make cash top-ups to my child's CPF retirement savings?
answer: To make cash top-ups to your child's CPF retirement savings (regardless his or her age), simply:1. Indicate your identification number as the giver of the cash top-up in the application2. Indicate your child's identification number as the recipient3. Select the relationship as "Others"Do note that givers of cash top-ups need to be at least 16 years old andcash top-ups to children will not qualify for tax relief.Find out more about the types ofcash top-ups which can enjoy tax relief.

question: I am making a top-up to myself from overseas. How can I set up a Singpass account if I do not have a mobile phone number registered in Singapore?
answer: If you wish to set up a Singpass account for your top-up application but do not have a mobile phone number registered in Singapore, you may contact theSingpass Helpdeskdirectly for assistance.

question: My child is below 16 years old. How do I transfer his Ordinary Account savings to his Special Account on his behalf?
answer: If your child is below 16 years old and wishes to transfer his Ordinary Account savings to his Special Account, you can complete thisapplicationon his behalf.

question: What is PayNow QR?
answer: PayNow QR is a convenient and faster way for you to make payments by scanning a QR code using your mobile banking app. It is also secure as it adopts the same high security standards adopted by the Singapore banking industry for fund transfers such as FAST and GIRO.You can use PayNow QR if you have accounts with any of the following banks in Singapore: Citibank Singapore Limited, DBS Bank/POSB, HSBC, Maybank, OCBC Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, United Overseas Bank, Bank of China, and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited.

question: What are the benefits of making top-ups via the PayNow QR?
answer: Making top-ups via PayNow QR is hassle-free.All you need to do is scan the QR code provided at the end of your online application, and the required details such as payment amount and transaction type will be automatically included. You do not have to manually enter any details, so you can complete the payment quickly and conveniently.

question: How do I make a top-up via PayNow QR?
answer: To make a top-up via PayNow QR, you can follow these steps:1. Submit anonline applicationvia the CPF website2. Scan the PayNow QR code with your PayNow participating bank's appIt is important to make payment as soon as possible, as the QR code will expire at the end of the day of application. If the QR code expires, you will need to submit a new application and make payment using the new QR code generated at the end of the application.To guide you on making a top-up via PayNow QR, watch theinstructional videoin your preferred language.For POSB/DBS bank account holders, please refer to the top-up steps using Digibank.LanguageEnglishChineseMalayTamilFor UOB bank account holders, please refer to the top-up steps using UOB TMRW.LanguageEnglishChineseMalayTamilFor OCBC bank account holders, please refer to the top-up steps using OCBC Digital.LanguageEnglishChineseMalayTamilAlternatively, you can submit an application via CPF Mobile app. Similarly, the PayNow QR code will be generated at the acknowledgement page. You just need to save the QR code on your device and upload it to your PayNow participating bank's mobile app to make payment.To top up using PayNow via CPF Mobile app, you can refer to the steps listed below.LanguageEnglishChineseMalayTamil

question: What is the maximum amount I can top up via PayNow QR?
answer: The daily transaction limit with PayNow QR is capped at $200,000, which is further subject to monthly and daily transaction limits imposed by your bank.See guides on how to change your bank’s transfer limits if you need to do so.

question: How long will it take for my top-up to be credited via PayNow QR?
answer: Top-ups via PayNow QR are generally credited almost instantly, upon successful payment.

question: What if my banking app is unable to scan the PayNow QR for my top-up application?
answer: If you are having trouble scanning the PayNow QR code for your top-up application, you should reach out to your bank for assistance.

question: What happens if I scan the generated PayNow QR code multiple times?
answer: To ensure that your cash top-up is processed smoothly, please only scan the PayNow QR code and make payment once as the code is only valid for a single payment. For subsequent or duplicate payments made using the same QR code, the payment will be refunded.If you need to make another top-up, you will need to submit a new application and obtain a new PayNow QR code.

question: I have made a PayNow QR payment but I am not able to see an immediate update to my CPF balance(s). Why is my CPF account balance(s) not updated immediately?
answer: Such cases are extremely rare and may arise due to intermittent network connectivity issues beyond CPF Board's control. As a result, the status of your PayNow payment may be delayed, and your CPF account balance(s) may not be updated instantly. Please do not worry as your CPF account balance(s) will be updated within 3-5 working days and you will receive an email notification if you have registered your email address with us. Please check your CPF account balance(s)/E-form status again after 3-5 working days and alert us immediately if your payment is still not updated.

question: How can I make recurring monthly or yearly top-ups conveniently via GIRO?
answer: You can make small and recurring cash top-ups via GIRO by following the steps below:Step 1:Set up a GIRO arrangementStep 2: Please allow one day for your GIRO bank account to be updated in the Board's record. Thereafter, please submit a request to makerecurring cash top-ups for retirement.Please note that you must completebothsteps for recurring cash top-ups via GIRO to be successful.Currently, the online application to set up a GIRO arrangement is only available for theseparticipating banks.If you encounter any difficulties in setting up GIRO, you maywrite to usfor assistance.

question: How can I change or delete my recurring cash top-up arrangement?
answer: You canchangeyour existing recurring cash top-up arrangement such as the amount and frequency of top-ups by following the steps below:Delete your existing recurring cash top-up arrangement in theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform.Create a new recurring arrangement via the sameformwith your revised amount and/or frequency of the top-ups.You candeleteyour existing recurring cash top-up arrangement via theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform. Your application will generally be processed instantly upon submission.

question: Can I set up more than one recurring cash top-up arrangement?
answer: Yes, you can make multiple recurring cash top-up arrangements for different recipients. You can add recurring top-up via theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform if you have already set up GIRO to make cash top-ups for retirement.If you have notset up GIROto make cash top-ups for retirement, you may do so via thislink.Please note that only one GIRO bank account can be used for your recurring cash top-up arrangements to your various top-up recipients.

question: Why are there no deductions from my bank account even though I have successfully made a recurring cash top-up arrangement?
answer: It could be due to one of the following reasons:If you have just made recurring cash top-up arrangements, the GIRO deduction might not have started yet. You may check the start month of your recurring cash top-up by accessing theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform, under “Who you are making recurring top-ups to”.If you have updated your GIRO bank account after 8th of the month, deductions will start from the following month instead of the current month.Find out more.

question: When is the deduction date of my recurring cash top-up arrangements?
answer: The deduction from your bank account takes place on the 15th of the month (or the next working day if 15th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday).If you set up a new GIRO to make recurring cash top-ups:GIRO deduction for your recurring cash top-up will take effect from the following month upon successful application of your recurring top-ups.If you have updated your GIRO bank account for recurring cash top-ups:Deductions from your GIRO bank account for your recurring cash top-up(s) will take effect from the current month if you have updated your bank account before the 8th of the month. Otherwise, the deductions will be made from your new bank account from the following month.Note: Please ensure that you maintain sufficient funds in your bank account for GIRO deductions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for each unsuccessful deduction.

question: How can I check my existing recurring cash top-up arrangements?
answer: You can check your existing recurring cash top-up arrangements, including the recipients, amount of cash top-ups, and frequency (monthly or yearly) by accessing theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform, under “Who you are making recurring top-ups to”.

question: What is the GIRO bank account used for my recurring cash top-up arrangement?
answer: If you have an existing GIRO arrangement, you can view your current bank account used for your GIRO by accessingSet up GIRO for cash top-ups for retirement form, under “Select bank”.

question: Why is the deduction still happening after I have successfully deleted my recurring cash top-up arrangement?
answer: To ensure that your deduction request takes effect from current month onwards, delete it at least three working days before the current monthdeduction. Else, the deduction will still proceed.

question: How can I update or terminate my GIRO bank account for recurring cash top-ups?
answer: You canupdateyour GIRO bank account for your recurring cash top-up bysetting up a new GIRO arrangement. If you have existing recurring top-up arrangements, the deductions could still be from your previous GIRO bank account for the current month.Find out more.You canterminateyour GIRO arrangement for your recurring cash top-up by submittingthis form. All monthly and/or yearly GIRO deductions for top-ups to your recipient(s) will cease.

question: How can I check the status of my cash top-up and/or CPF transfer application?
answer: You can check the status of your online application viaActivities. Once your cash top-up and/or CPF transfer application is successful, you will be able to find the details of the transaction on yourRetirement Dashboardunder the Retirement Sum Topping-Up History section.If you have submittedmultipleapplications, you can also review the status of each application underActivities. This will help you identify which transactions have been successfully processed, and you can also submit a new application if necessary.

question: My top-up is not reflected in my CPF account. Was the top-up unsuccessful?
answer: If your top-up is not reflected in your CPF accounts after the expiry of ourusual processing time, it might be due to one of the following reasons:You may have missed out in making payment for your cash top-up application.Find out how to submit a new application.You may have missed out in submitting supporting documents for first-time CPF transfers to a loved one.Find out what the required supporting documents are.We may require additional time to verify your application. We will contact you within five working days to request for more information.

question: Where can I find records of past top-ups made by me?
answer: You can check the top-up applications made by you in the last five years on yourRetirement Dashboardunder the Retirement Savings Topping-Up History section. For records beyond five years, you can refer to thisFAQon how to retrieve your or your recipient’s last 10 years of Yearly Statement of Account.

question: I made top-ups to my Special Account before turning 55. What will happen to the top-ups when I turn 55?
answer: When you turn 55, the top-ups made to your Special Account and accrued interest will betransferred to your Retirement Account (RA)up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS).Please note that top-up monies are meant to build up your retirement savings and cannot be withdrawn for other purposes. Read more onhow the top-ups will be used.If you are 55 or above and have excess savings above your FRS, you can apply towithdraw them for your immediate needsanytime. Alternatively, you canmake top-upsto your RA (up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum) to enjoy higher monthly payouts in retirement.

question: Can I withdraw the top-up monies if I have the Full Retirement Sum, or the Basic Retirement Sum if I own a property?
answer: You will not be able to withdraw the top-up monies as the higher interest rate and tax incentives are given to encourage members to build up their retirement savings. Allowing withdrawals after members have enjoyed these incentives would defeat the purpose of the topping-up scheme.

question: How will my monthly payouts change after topping up?
answer: If you are onCPF LIFE, topping up your Retirement Account will allow you to enjoy higher monthly payouts for life. If you arenot on CPF LIFE, the top-ups will generally allow you to receive higher payouts or receive payouts for a longer time.

question: Can I reverse my top-up?
answer: No, cash top-ups and CPF transfers are irreversible. The top-ups/CPF transfers to your Special Account or Retirement Account savings earn a higherinterest rateas the savings are locked in for the long-term. This is similar to the market practice where the interest earned on fixed deposits is higher compared to interest earned on savings deposits that are withdrawable anytime.

question: Will my cash top-ups or CPF transfers be refunded to me if the recipient passes away?
answer: Cash top-ups and CPF transfers will generally be treated as gifts to the recipient. Any unused cash top-ups and CPF transfers will be paid to the recipient's nominees based on hisCPF nomination. This is subject tosafeguards to prevent premature withdrawals.

question: What happens to my unused CPF transfers and cash top-ups to my recipient upon his demise or if he closes his CPF account upon leaving Singapore?
answer: Cash top-ups and CPF transfers will generally be treated as gifts to the recipient. Any unused cash top-ups or CPF transfers will be paid to the recipient's beneficiaries upon his demise, or to the recipient himself if he closes his CPF account and withdraws his CPF savings upon leaving Singapore. This is subject tosafeguards to prevent premature withdrawals.

question: How does CPF Board guard against premeditated early CPF withdrawals?
answer: There are policy safeguards to ensure givers' retirement adequacy before they can make CPF transfers to their loved ones. In addition, we have put in place a set of mechanisms to detect potential premature withdrawals. When such cases are detected, the CPF transfers will be refunded to the giver's CPF account, instead of being received by the recipient (for closure of CPF account upon leaving Singapore permanently) or the recipient's beneficiaries (for deceased cases) in cash.

question: Why was the cash top-up to my / my loved one's Special or Retirement Account refunded or partially refunded?
answer: Your top-up was refunded as you / your loved one had received other inflows at the same time as the cash top-up was made. These inflows had resulted in you / your loved one to meet the current Full Retirement Sum or Enhanced Retirement Sum (for members age 55 or above).

question: Can I transfer my top-ups made to my Special Account/ Retirement Account to other CPF accounts if I need to use them for other purposes such as housing or healthcare?
answer: No, such cash top-ups and CPF transfers are meant to boost your retirement savings to enable you to receive higher payouts. Hence, they cannot be used for other purposes or transferred to other CPF accounts such as your Ordinary Account or MediSave Account.Consider whether you would require the monies for other purposes (e.g. housing or healthcare expenses) before topping up to your Special Account/ Retirement Account.

question: I made a cash top-up to my spouse/sibling between 1 January 2024 and 16 February 2024 and instructed that I did not wish to claim tax relief. With the increase in income threshold from $4,000 to $8,000, how can I amend my instruction to claim tax relief?
answer: You cansubmit an applicationto amend your instructions to claim tax relief for top-ups made in 2024, if your recipient’s income in 2023 is between $4,000 and $8,000 (inclusive).If you indicated that you have a GIRO arrangement to make regular top-ups to your spouse or sibling in the application, your instructions for the GIRO arrangement will also be amended to claim tax relief for future GIRO top-ups.Please note thatother conditions to qualify for tax relief apply.

question: I have set up a GIRO arrangement to make top-ups to my spouse or sibling before 16 February 2024. With the increase in income threshold from $4,000 to $8,000, how can I amend my instructions for the GIRO arrangement to claim tax relief?
answer: The increase in income threshold for tax relief for cash top-ups to spouse or sibling will apply to cash top-ups made on 1 January 2024 or after. If you have a GIRO arrangement to make regular cash top-ups to your spouse or sibling and instructed to not claim tax relief previously, you cansubmit an applicationto amend your instructions to claim tax relief for top-ups from 2024 onwards.

question: I cannot remember if I had instructed that I want/ don't want to claim tax relief for my cash top-ups to my spouse or sibling in my application. How can I check?
answer: You may check your past top-up applications by logging in to the CPF website and checking under “my cpf” > “Activities”.

question: What is the change to the Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
answer: TheEnhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)was raised on 1 January 2025 from three times to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS). This provides CPF members aged 55 and above the option to voluntarily top up more to their Retirement Account (RA) for even higher monthly payouts in retirement.The ERS in 2025 is $426,000. This allows members to get higher CPF LIFE monthly payouts of up to $3,300 for life from age 65 through CPF top-ups.Learn more about the payouts you can receive.

question: How much CPF monthly payout can I receive if I top up to the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
answer: It depends on several factors, including the age when one sets aside the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) and when one starts payouts.The ERS in 2025 is $426,000.Illustrations on estimated monthly payouts for members who top up to ERS in 2025:Members who top up on reaching age 55 in 2025 can receive CPF LIFE monthly payouts of $3,100 – $3,300 for life from age 65.Members turning 65 in 2025 who had previously set aside their cohort Full Retirement Sum at age 55 can receive CPF LIFE monthly payouts of $2,500 – $2,700.You can use theMonthly payout estimatorto estimate your payouts if you top up to the raised ERS.

question: How can I check the amount that I can top up to my Retirement Account to reach the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
answer: You may check your top-up limit on yourRetirement Dashboardon 1 January 2025 once the Enhanced Retirement Sum is raised.Find outhow the top-up limit is computed.

question: Does the raising of the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) affect my Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) and Full Retirement Sum (FRS)?
answer: No, this will not affect yourBasic Retirement Sum (BRS) and Full Retirement Sum (FRS), which are determined when you turn age 55 and will remain the same for the rest of your life.If you are aged 55 and above, you can opt to top up more to your Retirement Account (RA), beyond your FRS, to receive higher monthly payouts in retirement. The maximum amount you can top up to your RA is the current year’sEnhanced Retirement Sum (ERS). With the raising of the ERS on 1 January 2025 from three times to 4 times of BRS, you will be able to top up more for even higher payouts.Find out more on how the BRS and FRS are determined.

question: I plan to top up my Retirement Account to the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum. When can I make the top-up?
answer: You can make your top-up anytime from 1 January 2025 onwards, once the Enhanced Retirement Sum is raised.Find outhow you can check the amount that you can top up.

question: With the closure of the Special Account and the raising of the Enhanced Retirement Sum, how much is the maximum amount that I can have in my Retirement Account?
answer: From 1 January 2025, the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) was raised to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum to allow members 55 and above to save more in the Retirement Account (RA) andreceive higher payouts, if they wish to do so.With the change, the ERS in 2025 is $426,0001, up from $308,700 in 2024. Hence, if you are aged 55 and above in 2025, you can save up to $426,000 in the RA. This allows members to get higher CPF LIFE monthly payouts of up to $3,300 for life from age 65 through CPF top-ups.Learn more about the payouts you can receive.As the ERS increases every January, you can make further top-ups every year for even higher payouts.1This is the limit for the savings set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received, plus retirement withdrawals).

question: How does the closure of my Special Account affect the amount of tax relief that I can earn when I top up my Retirement Account in cash?
answer: Cash top-ups to your Retirement Account (RA) up to the current year’sFull Retirement Sum (FRS)can qualify for tax relief of up to $8,000 per year. This will continue even after your Special Account (SA) is closed.For information, when members turn 55, their savings in their SA and Ordinary Account (OA) are transferred to their RA, up to their applicable FRS. The applicable FRS is the FRS in year they turn 55 and remains fixed for them thereafter, even when the FRS increases each year. Hence, members who have met their applicable FRS may still qualify for tax relief on their top-ups as the current year’s FRS may be higher than their applicable FRS.Illustration:Mr Lim turns 55 in 2024. His applicable FRS is $205,800. Assume he has $200,000 transferred from his SA and OA to his RA when he turns 55. He decides to make a cash top-up of $5,800 to his RA to meet his FRS in 2024. He can qualify for tax relief for his $5,800 top-up.In 2025, Mr Lim’s SA will be closed and his SA savings will be transferred to his OA since he has met his applicable FRS. However, as the FRS for 2025 is $213,000, he can get a tax relief of up to $7,200 (i.e. $213,000 - $205,800) if he makes additional cash top-ups to his RA.

question: With the closure of my Special Account, can I have the option to top up more than the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)?
answer: You are not able to top up more than the current year’sEnhanced Retirement Scheme (ERS)as the CPF system is designed to cater to the basic retirement needs of the broad majority of Singaporeans.With the raising of the ERS on 1 January 2025 from three times to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) (that is $426,000 in 2025), more than 99% of CPF members aged 55 or above will be able to transfer all their Special Account savings to their Retirement Account to continue to earn the higher long-term interest rate and receive higher payouts, should they wish to do so.You may consider transferring the savings in excess of the raised ERS to your loved ones’ CPF accounts, keep them in your OA to continue to earn 2.5% interest each year while retaining the flexibility to withdraw anytime. Alternatively, you can invest them under the CPF Investment Scheme – Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA), if you have assessed that CPFIS is suitable for you.

question: I am age 55 and above. How will the closure of Special Account (SA) affect my eligibility to voluntarily transfer my CPF savings to top up my own/loved ones' retirement savings?
answer: There are no changes to the eligibility rules on the transfer of CPF savings to top up your own/loved ones' retirement savings.When your Special Account is closed, your withdrawable SA savings (if any) will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA), and your available CPF savings for such top-ups will increase accordingly. You can check these amounts available for such top-ups via the Retirement Dashboard, after we complete the closure of your SA in the second half of January 2025.

question: What is the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme aims to help senior Singapore Citizens with lower retirement savings save more and boost their retirement payouts.Eligible memberswill receive a matching grant for every dollar of cash top-ups received in their Retirement Account, up to $2,000 per year from 1 Jan 2025 (increased from $600). Matching grant is capped at $20,000 over an eligible members’ lifetime.

question: What are the benefits of the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: Under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme, you will enjoy:Dollar-for-dollar matching grant for cash top-ups received, up to $2,000 per year and $20,000 in your lifetimeStable interest rates* up to 6% per annum on your cash top-upsCash top-ups and the matching grant will allow you to enjoy higher monthly payouts in retirementYour cash top-up made monthly for the year (12 months)Matching grant from the Government (next year)Increase in your retirement savings$50 / month$600 / year$1,200$88 / month$1,056 / year$2,112$168 / month$2,000 (Maximum) / year$4,016*Based on the current 4% interest rate floor on Retirement Account monies.

question: How does the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme work?
answer: We will assess youreligibilityfor the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) annually and will notify you via email or post at the beginning of the year if you are eligible. You can also check your eligiblity via theMRSS eligiblity checkerandRetirement Dashboard.If you are eligible and have received cash top-ups by 31 Dec of the year, you will receive a matching grant in your Retirement Account at the beginning of the following year. You can top up any amount using PayNow or GIRO. Top-ups can be made by anyone, including yourself or your loved ones.Learn more on how to make a cash top-uphere.

question: Who can make cash top-ups to recipients who are eligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: Anyone, including yourself,loved ones, employers or members of the community, can help members who are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme to receive the matching grant by making cash top-ups to their Retirement Account.Learn more on how to make a cash top-uphere.

question: I received an email notification on topping up my and/or my loved ones’ retirement savings. How do I know if the notification is indeed sent by CPF Board?
answer: Members will receive email notifications at the email address registered with the Board. You maycheck or update your email addresswhich you have earlier registered with us using your Singpass.To verify if the email you received is legitimate andavoid falling prey to phishing scams,Ensure that the sender's email address is correctly spelt and ends with "@e.cpf.gov.sg".Ensure that the hyperlinks or links you click on has a domain ending with “.gov.sg”.

question: How will the increase in the annual matching grant from $600 to $2,000 per year from 2025 help seniors better meet their retirement needs?
answer: Eligible seniors can top up more to their CPF retirement savings and receive the higher matching grant amount. Correspondingly, they will also receive higher monthly CPF payouts. For instance, a senior aged 55 in 2025 who makes a cash top-up of $2,000 per year over the next 10 years will see an increase in CPF retirement savings of at least $48,000 (inclusive of matching grants and CPF interest) in 2035, which translates to about a $260 increase in monthly CPF payouts*.*Estimation for a male member that starts payout at age 65 on the CPF LIFE Standard Plan.

question: What additional resources are available to help me better understand the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS)?
answer: You may refer to the table below for an infographic (available in English, Chinese, Malay and Tamil) and a video (with audio) which elaborate on the benefits of MRSS.To access these resources, you can click on the links below:InfographicVideoEnglishEnglishChinese (华文)Chinese (华文)Malay (Bahasa Melayu)Malay (Bahasa Melayu)Tamil (தமிழ்)Tamil (தமிழ்)

question: Why is there a lifetime cap of $20,000 to the matching grant when the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is enhanced from 2025?
answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is targeted at seniors with lesser means and lower retirement savings to help them save more for retirement. The enhancements to provide $2,000 matching grant annually, capped at $20,000 over a lifetime, are a significant increase from the current scheme, and can increase eligible seniors’ CPF savings by at least $48,000 in 10 years, which translates to about a $260 increase in monthly CPF payouts*.While it may not help all eligible seniors meet the Basic Retirement Sum, it is part of a broader set of schemes providing retirement adequacy support. Other schemes, such as the Majulah Package and the Silver Support Scheme, will also help boost the retirement adequacy of seniors.*Estimation for a male member who starts payout at age 65 on the CPF LIFE Standard Plan.

question: Who is eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: You will be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) for the year if you are aSingapore Citizenand meet the following criteria.​Age55 or above as of 31stDecember of the year​Retirement Account (RA) Savings*#​Less than $106,500^.​Average Monthly Income#​Not more than $4,000.This covers majority of senior workers.​Annual Value of Residence#​Not more than $21,000.​Property Ownership#​Own not more than one property.* RA savings refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any governments grants received), plus retirement withdrawals. If you are turning 55 in the assessment year and your RA has not been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be used for the eligiblity assessment instead.^ Basic Retirement Sum for 2025.# We assess the eligiblity based on the previous year's data because these are the latest data available.Find outhow you can check your eligibility for the MRSS.

question: How do I check if I am eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: You can check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) via theMRSS eligibility checker(no Singpass login required) andRetirement Dashboard.To view more details on the grant amount that you will receive in the beginning of the next year, you may log in to your Retirement Dashboard.

question: When will my eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme be assessed and do I need to apply?
answer: We will assess youreligibilityfor the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) annually at the beginning of the year. You do not need to apply.If you are eligible, we will notify you via email or post. You can also check your eligibility through theMRSS eligibility checker(no Singpass login required) andRetirement Dashboard.

question: Why am I not eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if my retirement savings are above the current Basic Retirement Sum?
answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to help senior Singapore Citizens with lower retirement savings save more and boost their retirement payouts. If your retirement savings are more than the current Basic Retirement Sum, you will not be eligible for the scheme as it is intended to provide additional support to those who need it the most.

question: Will I be eligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if I am turning 55 later this year?
answer: Yes, you will be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme as long as you are 55 years old in the assessment year and meet theeligibility criteria.If you are turning 55 this year and your Retirement Account has not been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be used for the eligibility assessment instead.You can check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) via theMRSS eligiblity checker(no Singpass required) andRetirement Dashboard.

question: If I am eligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year, will I be automatically eligible in the following years?
answer: No, your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is assessed annually. We will notify you at the beginning of the year if you are eligible.

question: I am eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year. Will I still be eligible if there are changes to my circumstance during the year?
answer: Yes, you will still be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) for the year even if your circumstances change (e.g. increase in monthly income) during the year. Your eligibility for MRSS will be assessed next year based on your new circumstances.However, do note that renouncing your Singapore citizenship during the year will make you ineligible for the scheme and matching grant.Find out about theconditions which you need to meetto receive and keep the matching grant.

question: Why am I not eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if my monthly income is above $4,000.
answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to help senior Singapore Citizens with lower retirement savings save more and boost their retirement payouts. The average monthly income of $4,000 will cover most senior workers. If your average monthly income is above $4,000, you will not be eligible for the scheme as it is intended to provide additional support to those who need it the most.

question: I was ineligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the past few years after turning 71 years old. With the lifting of the age cap of 70 from 2025, will my eligibility be revised for the past few years?
answer: No, the enhancements start from 2025. With the lifting of the age cap, eligible seniors above 70 can make cash top-ups and receive the same amount of Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) matching grant as those aged 55 to 70. The Government has also increased the annual matching grant amount to $2,000, compared to $600 before.

question: Why am I not eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if I am below 55 years old?
answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) helps boost the retirement payouts of older Singaporean Citizens aged 55 and above with lower retirement savings, who have a shorter runway to build up more retirement savings. MRSS is extended to them to help accumulate retirement savings.For those who are younger and have a longer runway to build their retirement savings, the Government provides various other support. These include the Workfare Income Supplement, which supplements the income and retirement savings of lower-wage workers, and the Retirement Sum Topping-Up scheme (RSTU), which provide tax relief on cash top-ups. These schemes boost retirement savings, allowing members to benefit from compounding interest and higher monthly payouts in retirement.

question: What do I need to do to receive the matching grant under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: To receive the matching grant, simply make your cash top up by 31 Dec of the year of eligibility.You can top up any amount using PayNow. For greater convenience, consider setting a GIRO arrangement to make small and regular top-ups. Top-ups can be made by anyone, including yourself or your loved ones.Your cash top-up made monthly for the year (12 months)Matching grant from the Government (next year)Increase in your retirement savings$50 / month$600 / year$1,200$88 / month$1,056 / year$2,112$168 / month$2,000 (Maximum) / year$4,016The matching grant will be credited to your RA in the beginning of next year. Matching grant is subjected to a lifetime limit of $20,000. Top-ups that attract MRSS matching grant will not qualify for tax relief.Learn more on how to make a cash top-uphere.

question: How do I make a cash top-up to receive the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: You can make a cash top-up to yourself or your loved ones’ Retirement Account (RA) via theCPF website or CPF mobile app. Your cash top-up will generally be credited almost instantly upon successful payment.Considermaking regular monthly or yearly cash top-ups conveniently via GIRO, without the hassle of completing the application form every time you top up.You may want to check whether you or your loved ones areeligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Schemebefore making a cash top-up.To make a top-up, you can refer to the following table:Application modePayment viaGuideWebRecurring cash top-upsvia GIROGuideOne-time cash top-upvia PayNow QRGuide(PDF, 0.1MB)Video GuideCPF Mobile appPayNow QROCBC DigitalEnglishChineseMalayTamilCPF transferGuide

question: Is there a minimum amount I need to top up to be eligible for the matching grant?
answer: There is no minimum amount of cash top-up needed to be eligible for the matching grant. However, the more you top up, the more grant you can receive, subject to an annual limit of $2,000 and a lifetime limit of $20,000.

question: I am turning 55 later this year. How can I top up if my Retirement Account has not been created yet?
answer: If your Retirement Account has not been created yet, you can top up to your Special Account (SA). Cash top-ups to your SA will be considered for matching grants under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme.

question: Why are CPF transfers not eligible for the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to encourage cash top-ups to senior Singapore Citizens with lower retirement savings to help them save more. Thus, only cash top-ups to eligible members will be matched.Members making CPF transfers can still benefit from the higher interest rate in the Retirement Account.

question: Why is there an annual cap of $2,000 of matching grant. Would the Government consider allowing eligible members to top up $20,000 at once and receive the lifetime matching grant of $20,000?
answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is targeted at seniors with lower retirement savings to help them save more for retirement. As member’s circumstances such as income and housing can change over time, the annual cap ensures that the scheme will help seniors who require the support over a longer period.

question: Why is tax relief removed for cash top-ups that attract matching grant under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme from 2025?
answer: As the cash top-ups serve to boost the retirement adequacy of seniors through the matching grant, tax relief is removed for cash top-ups which attract the matching grant. This is because the matching grant is already a benefit extended by the Government. Givers may continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 a year for cash top-ups that do not attract the MRSS matching grant, if they meet the criteria under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme (e.g., if the recipient has not met the current Full Retirement Sum).Learn more onhow the matching grant and tax relief are determined.Find out more on theconditions to qualify for tax relief.

question: What incentives are there for me to top up to my loved ones under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme when the tax relief is removed from 2025?
answer: Topping up to your loved ones’ CPF accounts helps them to build up more retirement savings and increases their monthly payouts in retirement. From 1 January 2025, recipients of cash top-ups who are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) can also receive a matching grant of up to $2,000 per year (an increase from $600 per year) from the Government, which will further boost their retirement savings.You may continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 a year for eligible cash top-ups that do not attract MRSS matching grants ($8,000 per year for top-ups to yourself and another $8,000 per year for top-ups to your loved ones).Learn more onhow this works.

question: I missed the deadline to top up for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme grant last year. Can I make a top-up this year for last year's grant?
answer: No, to qualify for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) grant, the cash top-up must be made by 31 December in the year of eligibility. This is stated in the eligibility notification sent at the beginning of the year of eligibility, and on the website.You can still make a top-up to earn interest rates* of up to 6% per annum and boost your monthly payouts. You can also enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 for cash top-ups made to yourself and your loved ones in each calendar year. Please note that cash top-ups which attract MRSS grant will not qualify for tax relief.*Based on the current 4% interest rate floor on Special and Retirement Account monies.

question: From 2025, how are the matching grants and tax relief determined for my cash top-ups made to a senior eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: From 1 January 2025, if you are making a cash top-up to a recipient eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS), your cash top-up of $2,000 will first enable your recipient to enjoy the matching grant of up to $2,000 per year from the Government, and will thus not be eligible for tax relief. You can continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 a year for your cash top-ups that do not attract the MRSS matching grant ($8,000 per year for top-ups to yourself and another $8,000 per year for top-ups to your loved ones).For example, if you make a cash top-up of $3,000 to your MRSS-eligible loved one, your loved one will first enjoy a matching grant of $2,000 from the Government, and you will be eligible for $1,000 of tax relief on your cash top-up that did not attract the matching grant.Find out more on theconditions to qualify for tax relief.

question: Can I make the top-up by cash or NETS under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: No, you can use PayNow or GIRO instead to make a cash top-up to yourself or your loved ones’ Retirement Account (RA).For PayNow, your cash top-up will generally be credited almost instantly upon successful payment.Consider making regular monthly or yearly cash top-ups conveniently via GIRO, without the hassle of completing the application form every time you top up.You may refer to this FAQ“How do I make a cash top-up to receive the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?”for the guide on how to top up.

question: How do I change or delete my recurring cash top-up arrangement to receive the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: If you want tochangeyour existing recurring cash top-up arrangement such as the amount and frequency, you can follow the steps below:Delete your existing recurring cash top-up arrangement in theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform.Create a new recurring arrangement via the sameformwith your revised amount and/or frequency of the top-ups.If you want todeleteyour existing recurring cash top-up arrangement, you can do so via theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform. Your application will generally be processed instantly upon submission.

question: How can I check my existing recurring cash top-up arrangements for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: You can check your existing recurring cash top-up arrangements, including the recipients, amount of cash top-ups, and frequency (monthly or yearly) by accessing theManage recurring cash top-ups for retirementform, under “Who you are making recurring top-ups to”.

question: Do I have to top up in a lump sum to be eligible for the matching grant?
answer: No, you can also make multiple smaller cash top-ups throughout the year. The matching grant is based on the total amount of top-ups you have received in the year, up to $2,000 per year.

question: How can I check if the matching grant has been credited to me?
answer: If you had made your cash top up by 31 Dec of the year of eligibility, the matching grant will be credited to your Retirement Account (RA) in the beginning of the next year. To find out if your matching grant has been credited, you can check yourTransaction Historyby logging in with your Singpass, or check your Transaction History in the CPF Mobile app.Please also note that the matching grant is subjected to a lifetime limit of $20,000. Top-ups that attract MRSS matching grant will not qualify for tax relief.The matching grant will be credited to your RA in the beginning of the next year.

question: Can I withdraw the matching grant?
answer: No, the top-up and matching grant are meant to boost your retirement savings for higher monthly payouts, hence they cannot be withdrawn in a lump sum. They will be paid out to you as part of your monthly payouts in retirement.

question: What if I pass away before receiving the matching grant?
answer: If you pass away, your matching grant will still be credited to your CPF account and paid out to yourbeneficiariestogether with any remaining CPF savings.

question: Will I still receive the full matching grant of $2,000 if my retirement savings exceed the current Basic Retirement Sum after topping up?
answer: Yes, you will receive the full matching grant of $2,000 as long as you are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the year, and the total amount of cash top-ups you received was at least $2,000.

question: When will I receive the matching grant?
answer: If you are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme and have received cash top-ups in that year, you can expect to receive the matching grant in your Retirement Account at the beginning of the following year.

question: What conditions must I meet in order to receive and retain the matching grant?
answer: To receive and retain the matching grant, you must:be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the year;have received cash top-ups during the year; andstill be a Singapore Citizen when the matching grant is credited to your Retirement Account (RA) at the beginning of the following year.Do note that cash top-ups are irreversible. Read more about theirreversibilitycondition.In an unlikely event where the cash top-up is reversed and you had already received the matching grant, the grant and any interest earned on it will be recovered from your CPF account.

question: I received Matched Retirement Savings Scheme matching grants in the past, before the $20,000 lifetime cap took effect in 2025. Will the past matching grants count towards this $20,000 lifetime cap?
answer: The lifetime cap will only be applied from 2025 onwards. Matching grants received in the past for cash top-ups made prior to 2025, will not count towards the $20,000 lifetime cap.

question: How do I check the amount of matching grant that I will receive?
answer: To find out the grant amount that you will receive in the beginning of the next year on the cash top-ups which you had received, you can log in to yourRetirement Dashboard.In addition, the Dashboard will provide you with the remaining grant amount, if any, which you can receive if you make further top-ups.

question: What is the voluntary top-up limit to my three CPF accounts?
answer: The maximum amount you can voluntarily top up is the difference between the CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 and the mandatory CPF contributions made for the calendar year.Do remember to consider your mandatory CPF contributions which you will be receiving for the calendar year, before making voluntary top-ups. If the total mandatory CPF contributions and voluntary top-ups exceed the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, any excess voluntary top-ups will be refunded without interest in the following year.

question: How do I check my voluntary top-up limit to my CPF accounts?
answer: When you make a cash top-up online, you will be shown the amount of top-up you can receive before you reach the top-up limit.You can follow these steps to check how much you can top up to your CPF accounts:Go to theTop up CPF accounts formLog in with your SingpassSelect “I wish to make a top-up to Myself” under “Recipient details”Your top-up limit will then be displayed.If the total mandatory CPF contributions and voluntary top-ups exceed the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, the excess voluntary top-ups will be refunded without interest the following year. Therefore, do remember to consider your mandatory CPF contributions which you will be receiving for the calendar year, before making voluntary top-ups.If you are making a top-up on another person’s behalf, please check with your recipient directly on the amount he can receive.

question: Is my voluntary top-up to the 3 CPF accounts  reversible?
answer: Voluntary top-ups made are irreversible.However, if the total mandatory CPF contributions and voluntary top-ups exceed the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, any excess voluntary top-ups will be refunded without interest. Therefore, do remember to consider your mandatory CPF contributions which you will be receiving for the calendar year, before making voluntary top-ups.

question: How can I top up to myself, my children or my loved ones' CPF accounts?
answer: You can make a top up viaTop up CPF accountsusing PayNow QR1.You will be prompted to key in your Recipient's NRIC/CPF Account Number if you are making a top-up on another person’s behalf.All applications and payments should reach CPF Board by the last day of the calendar year for it to be counted as the year’s CPF Annual Limit. Backdating of top-ups to previous years is not allowed.Tax relief is only applicable to self-employed persons, based on their assessable net trade income for the year of assessment.Find out more about tax relief for self-employed persons.You can find out more on whichvoluntary top-upis applicable to you.To make cash top-ups to yourself or a loved one on another person’s behalf, you are required to be up-to-date with your MediSave payable (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan) under theSelf-Employed Scheme. You may make payment for your MediSave payable via thepayment modes.Self-employed persons who meet theeligibility criteriawill continue to enjoy self-employed tax relief. However, the contributions allocated to your MediSave account will no longer be used to offset your MediSave payable (if any).1Subsequent or duplicate payments made using the same PayNow QR code will be refunded. To ensure that your cash top-ups are processed successfully, please only scan the PayNow QR code and make payment once. You will need to submit a new application each time you wish to make another top-up.

question: Why is there a limit set for my top-up to CPF accounts?
answer: There is a limit set as the CPF system is generally meant to cater to the needs of up to 80thpercentile of workers in Singapore. Higher income earners would have other means to supplement their retirement income.

question: How long does it take to process voluntary top-ups applications to my CPF accounts?
answer: The application relating to voluntary top-ups to CPF accounts will be processed as stated in the table below.ServiceProcessing TimeTop up CPF accountsAlmost immediatelyIf the top-up amount is not reflected in your CPF accounts, please check your CPF account balance after five working days as more time may be needed to process the transaction. Such cases may arise due to intermittent network connectivity issues beyond CPF Board's control.Please alert us immediately if your payment is still not updated in your CPF account balance after five working days.

question: Can I voluntarily top-up to my Ordinary Account only?
answer: Voluntary top-ups cannot be made solely to the Ordinary Account.You can make voluntary top-ups to:Special / Retirement Account only under theRetirement Sum Topping Up Scheme (RSTU)(tax relief available).MediSave Account only (tax relief available)CPF accountsVoluntary top-up is applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents only.You canfind outmore on which voluntary top-up is applicable to you.To make a top up to MediSave Account and/or CPF accounts, you are required to be up-to-date with your MediSave payable (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan) under theSelf-Employed Scheme. You may make payment for your MediSave payable via thepayment modes.Tax relief is only applicable to self-employed persons, based on their assessable net trade income for the year of assessment.Find out more about tax relief for self-employed persons.

question: Why are the excess voluntary top-ups only refunded in the following year?
answer: The CPF Annual Limit (AL) consists of both the Mandatory Contribution (MC) from your employer and Voluntary Contributions (VC) paid by you, if any. You are allowed to top up VC up to the CPF Annual Limit (AL) of the year.As the MC for December can be paid by January of the following year, any excess VC top-ups made for the preceding year can only be finalized and refunded in the following year.If your mandatory and voluntary CPF contributions have exceeded the CPF Annual Limit during the year, you canwrite to usto request for refund of the excess voluntary top-ups.

question: Why are the excess voluntary top-ups refunded with no interest?
